subclass.name: Shadow Master
subclassFeatures: Master of the Shadow Dance|Rogue||Shadow Master|Farover|17

subclassFeature.name: Affinity of the Moon
entries: Druids aligning with the Affinity of the Moon draw on the magic of the moon to transform themselves and to guard the wilds. They wander the deepest parts of the wilderness, where they might go for weeks on end before crossing paths with another person.

Changeable as the moon, a druid of this affinity might prowl as a great cat one moment, soar over the treetops as an eagle the next, and crash through the undergrowth in bear form to drive off a trespassing monster. The wild is in the druid’s blood.

subclassFeature.name: Bestial Prowess
entries: You gain the ability to transform between all of your different available {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape} forms while the feature is active. The size of the form you chose initially stays the same. You can switch between your forms using a bonus action, without having to revert back to a humanoid first.

Additionally, you can use an unarmed strike as a bonus action while in a Wild Shape form. You can use either Strength or Dexterity for the attack and damage rolls, and the attack deals {@dice 1d2} + modifier damage.

subclassFeature.name: Adaptive Recovery
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can convert your magic to heal yourself even while transformed. While you are transformed by {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape}, you can use a bonus action to expend one spell slot to regain {@dice 1d8} hit points per level of the spell slot expended.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Strikes
entries: Starting at 10th level, elemental forces imbue your attacks. Whenever you initially spend a Channel Nature and transform into a {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape} form, choose one of the following damage types: Acid, Cold, Fire, or Lightning.

While in the form, your melee attacks deal an additional {@dice 1d6} damage of the type you chose. Your form also displays signs of the chosen damage type. For example, if you choose fire, your fur might flicker with small, harmless embers. You choose the details.

subclassFeature.name: Apex Predator
entries: At 14th level, your types of {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape} forms become their apex versions, and gain the following benefits:
{@bold {@italic Agile.}} Your Agile forms ignore difficult terrain, and you gain +2 to attack rolls and proficiency in Dexterity ability checks and saving throws while in the form.
{@bold {@italic Strong.}} Your Strong forms carrying capacity is doubled, and you gain +2 to damage rolls and proficiency in Strength ability checks and saving throws while in the form.
{@bold {@italic Tough.}} Your Tough forms can be size Huge, and you gain +1 AC and proficiency in Constitution ability checks and saving throws while in the form.

subclassFeature.name: Affinity of Dreams
entries: Druids who align with the Affinity of Dreams often venture to and reside in regions that have strong ties to the Feywild and its dreamlike realms. The druids` guardianship of the natural world makes for a natural alliance between them and good-aligned fey. These druids seek to fill the world with dreamy wonder. Their magic mends wounds and brings joy to downcast hearts, and the realms they protect are gleaming, fruitful places, where dream and reality blur together and where the weary can find rest.

subclassFeature.name: Bloom of Spring
entries: When you heal a creature with your {@classFeature Nature's Aid|Druid (reworked)|Farover|2||Healing Blossoms}, the creature also recovers hit points equal to half the rolled amount at the beginning of its next turn.

Additionally, you can use your Healing Blossoms feature as a {@status concentration} spell. If your Healing Blossoms affects a creature with no missing hit points, you can decide to delay the both the initial and secondary healing of the ability by holding onto it like you would a concentration spell* for up to 1 minute.

While you maintain concentration, whenever an affected creature takes any damage to fall below full hit points, Healing Blossoms triggers to heal that creature. Since the feature has an initial and secondary healing, both heals follow this rule, and if the initial heal doesn`t heal the creature to full hit points, the secondary heal then also triggers immediately after.
{@italic (*FO: Full concentration points)}

subclassFeature.name: Growth of Summer
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can spend spell slots to empower your {@classFeature Nature's Aid|Druid (reworked)|Farover|2||Healing Blossoms}. When using Healing Blossoms, you can expend one spell slot to grant the ability an additional {@dice 1d6} healing per slot level used.

In addition, you can call upon the forces of nature to protect you and your allies when you settle down for a rest. At the start of a short or long rest, you can touch a tree, shrub, or other similar plant in your vicinity to awaken. You can only do this if such plants are alive and present in your area.

Your DM chooses statistics appropriate for the awakened plant, such as the statistics for the {@link awakened shrub or tree|https://5e.tools/bestiary.html#awakened%20zurkhwood_oota,flstsource:idrotf=0,flopsource:extend,flsttype:plant=1,floptype:extend,fbsr:awakened}. The plant is controlled by the DM. The awakened plant can not move, but it will protect you and any designated allies for the duration of your short or long rest. At the end of the rest, the plant loses its magic, and returns to being a normal plant.

subclassFeature.name: Hidden Paths
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can use the hidden, magical pathways that some fey use to traverse space in the blink of an eye. As a bonus action on your turn, you can teleport up to 60 feet to an unoccupied space you can see. Alternatively, you can use your action to teleport one willing creature you touch up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space you can see.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain one use of it when you finish a short rest, and all uses of it when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Purifying Magic
entries: Starting at 14th level, whenever you cast a spell of 1st-level or higher on a target, you can end one disease, poison, or one of the following conditions affecting the creature: {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, or {@condition stunned}.

subclassFeature.name: Affinity of the Land
entries: The Affinity of the Land covers the mystics and sages among druids who safeguard ancient knowledge and rites through a vast oral tradition. These druids meet within sacred circles of trees or standing stones to whisper primal secrets in Druidic. Through these secrets, druids of the land have developed a deep connection with the magic of nature.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Cantrip
entries: You learn one additional druid {@link cantrip|https://5e.tools/spells.html#control%20flames_xge,flstlevel:0=1,floplevel:extend,flmtclasses:b1,flstclass:druid=1,flopclass:extend} of your choice. This cantrip doesn`t count against the number of druid cantrips you know.

subclassFeature.name: Natural Recovery
entries: You can regain magical energy by sitting in meditation and communing with nature. During a short rest, you choose expended spell slots to recover. The spell slots can have a combined level that is equal to or less than half your druid level (rounded up), and none of the slots can be 6th level or higher. This recovery does not stack with any other rules or features that allows you to recover spell slots on short rests.

subclassFeature.name: Domain Spells
entries: Your mystical connection to the land infuses you with the ability to cast certain spells. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to spells connected to the domain where your druidic circle is located. Choose the domain—arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, mountain, subterranean, or swamp—and consult the associated list of spells.

Once you gain access to a circle spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn’t count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. Spell that don’t appear on the druid spell list are considered druid spells for you.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Seedlings
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to sow your spells into small seedlings. When you complete the casting of a spell, you can decide to hold its potential by planting it in the ground within 5 feet of you, and the spell sprouts as a small magical seedling. You must make all decisions regarding the spell at the time you cast it. The spell can not have a range of only self, nor can it affect only yourself.

Within the next 10 minutes, you can direct your sown spell to bloom and produce the spell’s effects as a reaction, as long as you can see it. The spell works normally, but its point of origin is the seedling, instead of you. You can have only have one sown spell at a time, and if you don’t trigger the spell within 10 minutes, it withers and the spell is lost. A creature can notice the clearly magical seedling with a successful {@skill Perception} check against your spell save DC.

subclassFeature.name: Feywalker
entries: At 10th level, the magic of the Feywild grants you the ability to travel mentally or physically across great physical distances.

When you finish a short rest, you can cast one of the following spells, without expending a spell slot or requiring material components: {@spell Dream} (with you as the messenger), {@spell Scrying|farover}, or {@spell Malakai's Teleportation Circle|farover}.

This use of malakai’s teleportation circle is special. Rather than teleporting to a permanent teleportation circle, it instead teleports you and up to 8 willing creatures of your choosing in your vicinity to the last location where you finished a long rest on your current plane of existence. If you haven’t taken a long rest on your current plane, the spell fails but isn’t wasted.
Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Sanctuary
entries: When you reach 14th level, creatures of the natural world sense your connection to nature and become hesitant to attack you. When a beast, elemental, fey, or plant creature attacks you, that creature must make a Wisdom saving throw against your druid spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature must choose a different target, or the attack automatically misses. On a successful save, the creature is immune to this effect for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Path of the Titan
entries: The titan barbarian brandishes inhuman strength and massive weapons to overpower mere mortals.

subclassFeature.name: Titan's Grip
entries: Starting when you choose this path at 3rd level, you can use two-weapon fighting even when the melee weapons you are wielding aren't light.
Additionally, when you roll for damage with a weapon that has the versatile property that you are wielding in one hand, you treat it as if you are wielding it with two hands.
You can now also draw or stow two weapons when you would normally be able to draw or stow one.

subclassFeature.name: Overpowering Grasp
entries: At 6th level, your grapples become more oppressive. When you successfully grapple a target, the target has disadvantage on Strength and Dexterity saving throws for the duration of the grapple.

While grappling a target, you can also attempt to wrestle your target into the ground as a bonus action. If you succeed in an Athletics contest with the target, your target falls prone in addition to being grappled.

subclassFeature.name: Ambidextrous Power
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can now use two-weapon fighting even when the melee weapons you are wielding have the heavy or the two-handed properties.

In addition, due to your immense grip strength, you have advantage on Strength based rolls to maintain possession of your weapons against disarming effects, and you gain a climbing speed equal to half your base movement speed.

subclassFeature.name: Titanic Adversary
entries: Starting at 14th level, your physical prowess resembles that of an imposing titan avatar.

Once per short rest when you enter your rage, you gain temporary hit points equal to your barbarian level, and each creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier) or be frightened of you until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Master
entries: The Shadow Master focuses on stealth and survivability, utilizing theatricality and deception through physical means. Shadow masters manipulate the forces of the shadows and the unseen to their advantage.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Dance
entries: At 3rd level, you can enter a Shadow Dance, enveloping yourself in dark smoke resembling shadows. You can enter a Shadow Dance for free once per turn, and it lasts until the beginning of your next turn. Your Shadow Dance ends early if you are incapacitated. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your proficiency modifier. You restore one charge of Shadow Dance on a short rest, and all charges on a long rest.
During your Shadow Dance, you gain +10 movement speed. You also choose one of the following benefits:

entries.name: Elusive
entries: Melee attack rolls against you have disadvantage for the duration.

entries.name: Impervious
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects for the duration.

entries.name: Unforeseen
entries: Your amount of Sneak Attack dice rolled is increased by one for the duration.

subclassFeature.name: Dark Arts
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to use smoke and mirrors very effectively. You can cast the {@spell minor illusion} cantrip, and you can also cast the {@spell darkness} spell once per short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Shadow Dance
entries: At 9th level, the benefits of your Shadow Dance are empowered:

entries.name: Elusive
entries: Also increases your AC by 1 for the duration.

entries.name: Impervious
entries: Also enhances your Evasion ability to grant you the same effect against all spells and other magical effects for the duration.

entries.name: Unforeseen
entries: Your amount of Sneak attack dice rolled is increased by an additional one for the duration.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Step
entries: At 9th level, your mastery in the darkness grants you unnatural mobility. By spending movement, you can teleport into an unoccupied space of dim light or darkness that you can see, up to a distance away equal to half the movement you decide to spend.

subclassFeature.name: Shady Tricks
entries: Starting at 13th level, your skills in the manipulation of vision grants you the following features:

items: While holding a small weapon or item in your hand, you can pocket or stow away the item with a quick flick of the wrist, seeming to anyone else that your item disappeared into thin air. Anyone who passes a Perception check (DC 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Sleight of Hand mod) can spot what really happened to the item.

When another character within 30 feet of you makes a Perception or Investigation check, you can use your reaction to subtly wave your hand and interfere with their senses, imposing disadvantage on the check. The target character will have no idea the effect happened, unless it is looking directly at you.

subclassFeature.name: Master of the Shadow Dance
entries: At 17th level you become a master of dancing with the shadows. When you activate your Shadow Dance, you can choose two of the three benefits.

subclassFeature.name: Sentinel
entries: Those who pursue the archetypical sentinel choose defense over offense as their primary combat strategy. Employing techniques primarily meant to guard allies from harm, the sentinel uses quick thinking, reflexes, and a sturdy exterior to keep those in danger out of harms way.

subclassFeature.name: Intervene
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can quickly interpose yourself between and enemy and an ally in the midst of combat.

As a reaction when a creature within half of your movement speed away is hit by a melee or ranged attack, you can move to them and interpose yourself between them and the threat. You must end your movement within 5 feet of the target, and while moving you do not provoke attacks of opportunity. After moving, you then become the new target of the attack roll. You can use this feature after the attack roll has been made, but before any of its effects or damage are determined. You must be wearing a shield to use this feature.
You can use this feature twice at 3rd level. You gain one additional use at both 9th and at 15th level. You regain one use of this feature on a short rest, and all uses on a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Resolute Protection
entries: At 7th level, your unwavering watchfulness and sharp mind grant you the following benefits:

items: When you make a Charisma, Intelligence, or Wisdom saving throw, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded down) to the roll.
You can sleep normally in heavy armor.
If you are surprised at the beginning of combat and aren't incapacitated, you can still use your Intervene feature during the first round of combat as normal.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Stance
entries: At 10th level, you can enter a defensive stance on your turn as an action. You must be wearing a shield to use this feature.

This stance lasts until you move, are incapacitated, or knocked prone. While in the defensive stance, you can add half your proficiency bonus (rounded down) to your AC and your Dexterity saving throws. You also grant the same benefits to any allied creatures within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Shielding
entries: At 15th level, your mastery with a shield reaches a level of expertise where you're able to block spells and magical effects.

While you are in your defensive stance, and you or an allied creature within 5 feet of you is the target of a spell or magical effect, you can choose to make a Constitution ability check as a reaction. The DC for a spell is 5 + the spellcasters level + the spells level, and a magical effect is equal to the CR of the creature who used the magical effect. On a success, you successfully block the magic, nullifying the effects of it.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Guardian
entries: At 18th level, you reach the exalted status of a master guardian in battle. You gain the following benefits:

items: When you use your intervene feature, you have resistance to all the damage you take from the intervened attack.

When you use your reaction on your spell shielding feature and pass the DC of blocking the spell or magical effect by at least 5, you can reflect the spell or magical effect back at the original caster, using the same range, spell save DC, and spell attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Elemental Magic
entries: Your innate power comes from a direct link to all four of the elemental planes. Those who harness the combined power of the elements tie their heritage to powerful, primordial elementals that have existed in the world for thousands of years, such as a phoenix or tempest.

Elemental sorcerers feel the call of nature much like druids do, but their goals and purpose in their actions often differ. Often feeling slightly out of place in an urban environment, elementalists are never completely at peace until they are near a flowing river, wildfire, or a raging storm.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Arsenal
entries: You learn additional spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Elemental Spells table. Each of these spells counts as a sorcerer spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of sorcerer spells you know.
Additionally, when you reach 3rd level and learn the Metamagic feature, you learn the Transmuted Spell metamagic option listed below as an additional metamagic option.

subclassFeature.name: Transmuted Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals a type of damage from the following list, you can spend 1 sorcery point to change that damage type to one of the other listed types: acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, thunder.

subclassFeature.name: Curse of the Elements
entries: When you choose this origin at 1st level, you learn the ability to infuse your spells with an elemental curse.

When you hit a creature with a cantrip's attack or when a creature fails a saving throw against your cantrip, you can curse the target until the end of your next turn or until you curse a different creature with this feature.

Once per turn when you cast a spell, you can trigger the curse if that spell deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage to the cursed target. Doing so subjects the target to the appropriate additional effect below, and then the curse ends if the spell isn't a cantrip (you choose the effect to use if more than one effect applies):
Additionally, when you reach 3rd level and learn the Metamagic feature, you learn the Transmuted Spell metamagic option listed below as an additional metamagic option.

entries.name: Acid/Poison damage
entries: If the affected target takes acid or poison damage from your spell, the target has disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Cold damage
entries: If the affected target takes cold damage from your spell, the target's speed is also reduced by 15 feet until the end of your next turn. If the spell already reduces the target's speed, use whichever reduction is greater.

entries.name: Fire damage
entries: If the affected target takes fire damage from your spell, the target takes additional fire damage equal to your Charisma modifier.

entries.name: Lightning/Thunder damage
entries: If the affected target takes lightning or thunder damage from your spell, the target is also pushed back 10 feet. If the target would be moved by your spell, you can increase the distance it is moved by 10 feet.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You recover all uses of this feature on a short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Liquid Defense
entries: At 6th level, choose either acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage to gain resistance against.

In addition, you also gain the ability to defend yourself by momentarily assuming a watery form. As a reaction when you are hit by an attack and take bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage from it, you can reduce that damage by an amount equal to your sorcerer level plus your Charisma score, and then you can move up to 30 feet without provoking opportunity attacks.
Once you use this special reaction, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Interplanar Trigger
entries: Starting at 14th level, whenever you score a critical hit against a target with a spell that deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, poison, or thunder damage, you momentarily summon an elemental to fight for you.
Depending on the type of damage you deal, you summon one of the following elementals. If your spell deals multiple types of damage, you may choose which one is summoned.

items: Acid/Poison damage summons an {@creature earth elemental}.
Cold damage summons a {@creature water elemental}.
Fire damage summons a {@creature fire elemental}.
Lightning/Thunder damage summons an {@creature air elemental}.

entries: The elemental appears within 5 feet of your target after the critical hit, and it takes its turn immediately after yours. The elemental acts on its own, but it attacks your enemies, prioritizing the target that was critically hit by your spell. The elemental fights for one round, and then disappears at the beginning of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Cauterization
entries: At 18th level, your Constitution score increases by 2, up to a maximum of 22.

In addition, your fire spells can now mitigate wounds and restore you. When you expend a spell slot to cast a spell that includes a fire damage roll, you regain hit points equal to the slot's level + your Charisma modifier.

subclassFeature.name: Beast Conclave
entries: Many rangers are more at home in the wilds than in civilization, to the point where animals consider them kin. Rangers of the Beast Conclave develop a close bond with a beast, then further strengthen that bond through the use of magic.

subclassFeature.name: Animal Companion
entries: At 3rd level, you learn to use your magic to create a powerful bond with a creature of the natural world.
With 8 hours of work and the expenditure of 50 gp worth of rare herbs and fine food, you call forth an animal from the wilderness to serve as your faithful companion.

You normally select your companion, and it can be any beast with a CR of at most 1/8. A beast with a flying speed loses its flying speed, and it becomes a hover speed instead. You can also use the stat block of one such beast for another kind of beast you would want as well. However, your DM might pick one of these animals for you, based on the surrounding terrain and on what types of creatures would logically be present in the area.
At the end of the 8 hours, your animal companion appears and gains all the benefits of your Companion's Bond ability. You can have only one animal companion at a time.

If your animal companion is ever slain, the magical bond you share allows you to return it to life. With 8 hours of work and the expenditure of 25 gp worth of rare herbs and fine food, you call forth your companion's spirit and use your magic to create a new body for it. You can return an animal companion to life in this manner even if you do not possess any part of its body.
If you use this ability to return a former animal companion to life while you have a current animal companion, your current companion leaves you and is replaced by the restored companion.

subclassFeature.name: Companion's Bond
entries: Your animal companion gains a variety of benefits while it is linked to you.
The animal companion loses its Multiattack action, if it has one.

The companion obeys your commands as best it can. Your companion takes its turn immediately after yours, and you determine its actions, decisions, attitudes, and so on. If you are incapacitated or absent, your companion acts on its own.
When using your Natural Explorer feature, you and your animal companion can both move stealthily at a normal pace.

Your animal companion has abilities and game statistics determined in part by your level. Your companion uses your proficiency bonus rather than its own. In addition to the areas where it normally uses its proficiency bonus, an animal companion also adds its proficiency bonus to its AC.
Your animal companion gains proficiency in two skills of your choice. It also becomes proficient with all saving throws.
For each level you gain after 3rd, your animal companion gains an additional hit die and increases its hit points accordingly.

Whenever you gain the Ability Score Improvement class feature, your companion's abilities also improve. Your companion can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or it can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, your companion can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature unless its description specifies otherwise.

Your companion shares your alignment, and has a personality trait and a flaw that you can roll for or select from the tables below. Your companion shares your ideal, and its bond is always, 'The ranger who travels with me is a beloved companion for whom I would gladly give my life.'

subclassFeature.name: Beast's Defense
entries: Starting at 7th level, your companion has advantage on all saving throws.
In addition, your companion can now be a beast with a CR of at most 1/4.

subclassFeature.name: Bloodthirst
entries: Starting at 11th level, your companion develops a taste for blood. When your companion takes the Attack action on its turn to attack a {@condition wounded|farover} target, or causes a target to be {@condition wounded|farover} with the attack, your companion can attack twice, instead of once.
In addition, your companion can now be a beast with a flying speed and a CR of at most 1/2.

subclassFeature.name: Superior Beast's Defense
entries: At 15th level, whenever an attacker that your companion can see hits it with an attack, it can use its reaction to halve the attack's damage against it.

subclassFeature.name: Deep Stalker Conclave
entries: Most folk descend into the depths of the Underdark only under the most pressing conditions, undertaking some desperate quest or following the promise of vast riches. All too often, evil festers beneath the earth unnoticed, and rangers of the Deep Stalker Conclave strive to uncover and defeat such threats before they can reach the surface.

subclassFeature.name: Deep Stalker Magic
entries: At 3rd level, you have darkvision out to a range of 90 feet. If you already have darkvision, you increase its range by 30 feet.

You also learn additional spells at 3rd, 5th, 9th, 13th, and 15th level. Once you gain a deep stalker spell, it counts as a ranger spell for you but doesn't count against the number of rangers spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Underdark Scout
entries: At 3rd level, you master the art of the ambush. On your first turn during combat, you gain a +10 bonus to your movement speed and if you use the normal attack action on that turn, you can make one additional attack.

Additionally, when you are in dim light or darkness, you can use your Steady Aim feature to attack with an added element of camouflage. When doing so, in addition to the advantage granted by the feature, your first ranged attack of the turn deals an extra {@dice 1d6} damage.

You are also adept at evading creatures that rely on darkvision. When standing still and taking no actions in dim light or darkness, you are invisible to such creatures attempting to detect you with darkvision.

subclassFeature.name: Iron Mind
entries: By 7th level, you have honed your ability to resist the mind-altering powers of your prey. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws. If you already have this proficiency, you instead gain proficiency in Intelligence or Charisma saving throws (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Stalker's Fury
entries: At 11th level, you learn to attack with such unexpected speed that you can turn a miss into another strike. Once on each of your turns when you miss with a weapon attack, you can make another weapon attack as part of the same action.

subclassFeature.name: Shadowy Dodge
entries: Starting at 15th level, you can dodge in unforeseen ways, with small wisps of shadow around you. Whenever a creature makes an attack roll against you and doesn't have advantage on the roll, you can use your reaction to impose disadvantage on it. You must use this feature before you know the outcome of the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Marksman Conclave
entries: Some rangers seek to master weapons to better protect civilization from the terrors of the wilderness. Members of the Marksman Conclave learn specialized fighting techniques for use against the most dire threats, from rampaging ogres and hordes of orcs to towering giants and terrifying dragons.
At 3rd level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

entries.name: Colossus Slayer
entries: Your tenacity can wear down the most potent foes. When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, the creature takes an extra {@dice 1d8} damage if it's below its hit point maximum. You can deal this extra damage only once per turn.

entries.name: Giant Killer
entries: When a Large or larger creature within 5 feet of you hits or misses you with an attack, you can use your reaction to attack that creature immediately after its attack, provided that you can see the creature. Disadvantage imposed on ranged weapons from being within 5 feet of an enemy do not apply to this attack.

entries.name: Terminator
entries: You are adept at finishing off foes. Any hit you score with a weapon attack against a creature that is {@condition wounded|farover} is a critical hit.
In addition, you can make a single weapon attack on your turn as a bonus action if you attack a {@condition wounded|farover} target.
At 7th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

entries.name: Escape the Horde
entries: Opportunity attacks against you are made with disadvantage.

entries.name: Multiattack Defense
entries: When a creature hits you with an attack, you gain a +4 bonus to AC against all subsequent attacks made by that creature for the rest of the turn.

entries.name: Steel Will
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, and {@condition paralyzed}.
At 11th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

entries.name: Pirouette Strike
entries: You can use your action to quickly spin around and make a weapon attack against any number of creatures within 5 feet of you, with a separate attack roll for each target.

entries.name: Sharpshooter
entries: When you use your Steady Aim feature and have advantage for the first ranged attack roll you make, you can reroll one of the dice once.
At 15th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

entries.name: Evasion
entries: You can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as a red dragon's fiery breath or a lightning bolt spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

entries.name: Stand Against the Tide
entries: When a hostile creature misses you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to force that creature to repeat the same attack against another creature (other than itself) of your choice.

entries.name: Uncanny Dodge
entries: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack's damage against you.

subclassFeature.name: Monster Slayer Conclave
entries: Emulating the techniques and training of the infamous guild of slayers, you have dedicated yourself to hunting down creatures of the night and wielders of grim magic. A Monster Slayer seeks out vampires, dragons, evil fey, fiends, and other magical threats. Trained in slayer techniques to overcome such monsters, monster slayers are experts at unearthing and defeating mighty, mystical foes.

subclassFeature.name: Monster Slayer Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Monster Slayer Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter's Sense
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use your Favored Enemy feature to quietly observe a creature of any non-humanoid type, not just your favored enemy types.

subclassFeature.name: Slay the Prey
entries: Starting at 3rd level, when you deal damage to a creature affected by your Hunter's Mark feature, you can roll an additional hunter's mark damage die.

subclassFeature.name: Supernatural Defense
entries: At 7th level, you gain extra resilience against your prey's assaults on your mind and body. Whenever the target of your Hunter's Mark feature forces you to make a saving throw and whenever you make an ability check to escape that target's grapple, add {@dice 1d6} to your roll.

subclassFeature.name: Countershot
entries: At 11th level, you gain the ability to thwart someone else's magic. When you see a creature casting a spell or teleporting within 60 feet of you, you can use your reaction to quickly attack it with a ranged weapon, attempting to magically foil it. Make either a Strength or Dexterity ability check. Depending on what your target is casting, the DC to interrupt it is 5 + the spellcasters level + the spells level. If you succeed on the skill check, the targets spell or teleport fails and is wasted.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Slayer's Riposte
entries: At 15th level, you gain the ability to counterattack when your prey tries to sabotage you. If the target of your Hunter's Mark forces you to make a saving throw, you can use your reaction to make one weapon attack against the target. You make this attack immediately before making the saving throw. If your attack hits, your save automatically succeeds, in addition to the attack's normal effects.

subclassFeature.name: Cult of Demonology
entries: The cult of demonology specializes in knowledge and mastery over fiends, demons and devils. They study the ways of summoning from the shadow plane, and subjugation on the material plane.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The cult of demonology lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Summon Gloombat
entries: Beginning when you choose this cult at 2nd level, you learn how to summon a meager fiend called a {@creature summoned gloombat|farover|Gloombat} into your service. The summoning of the gloombat works as a part of your warlock {@classFeature Demonic Summoning|Warlock (reworked)|farover|5} feature, and the gloombat is considered a 0th level spell for the purpose of soul shard damage. The gloombat is a small, nearly mindless fiend which can not communicate in any way, but will follow your orders as best it can. The gloombat can't attack in any way, but it can take other actions as normal. You do not suffer any excess damage when your gloombat dies.

subclassFeature.name: Insidious Command
entries: Beginning when you choose this cult at 2nd level, you gain the following features for your {@classFeature Demonic Summoning|Warlock (reworked)|farover|5} feature:

items: Summoning and re-summoning a fiend for you is now an action, instead of a 10 minute ritual.

When you cast a spell with either a range of touch, or a melee spell attack, your summon can spend its reaction to deliver the spell as if it had cast the spell, and you can can also cast these spells on your summon from range as long as you are within 100 feet and you can see it.

Once per short rest, you can transfer health from your summon to you as a bonus action. You must be within 100 feet and you must see your summon to do this. Your summon loses half of its current hit points, and you then regain a number of hit points equal to this.

subclassFeature.name: Demonic Empowerment
entries: Starting at 6th level, when your summon is within 30 feet and in line of sight, you can expend a warlock spell slot as an action to temporarily empower your summon.

When initially casting the empowerment, you can choose to teleport and switch places with your summon. Your summon also gains {@dice 1d6} temporary hit points for every level of the spell slot used for the empowerment.

While maintaining concentration for the duration of the empowerment, which lasts for up to 1 minute, your summon adds one additional die to all of it's damage rolls, and it can attack twice, instead of once, whenever it takes the Attack action on its turn.

subclassFeature.name: Summon Quasit
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can summon a {@creature summoned quasit|farover|Quasit} with your Demonic Summoning feature. Summoning a Quasit is considered a 1st level spell for the purpose of Soul Shard damage.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Banishment
entries: At 10th level, you learn the spell {@spell Banishment} if you do not already know it. If you already know the spell, you can learn another warlock spell instead, but regardless this spell does not count towards your maximum spells known.
You can cast Banishment once per long rest without expending a spell slot, and you can also cast it using soul shards.

Your Banishment is also stronger against fiends. If you successfully banish a fiend with a CR of at most half your level (rounded down) with the spell, the spells duration becomes instantaneous, and the banished fiend does not return.

subclassFeature.name: Master Subjugator
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can attempt to subjugate any fiend, devil or demon you encounter into your service with the {@classFeature Demonic Summoning|Warlock (reworked)|farover|5} ability, replacing any current summon you may have. Attempting to subjugate a demon with this feature costs a soul shard, and is considered a 5th level spell for the purpose of soul shard damage.

While the target fiend is within 60 feet of you, as an action, you can force it to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, a link of dark, magical chains surrounds the fiends body, attempting to subjugate it. If the target succeeds on three of these saves, it is released from any chains and is immune to this ability for 24 hours. If the target fails three of these saves, the three links of chains bind the fiend into your control.
While in your control, the subjugated fiend will make a Wisdom saving throw at disadvantage after every hour since it was subjugated. On a successful save, the fiend is released.
The subjugated fiend will be under your control, similarly to the Demonic Summoning feature, but with the following changes:

items: You must maintain concentration (5 points) for this feature to remain active.
The subjugated fiend can not be sent to a pocket dimension.

Releasing the subjugated fiend only releases it from your control. If a fiend has been successfully subjugated by you within the last 24 hours, it has advantage on any saving throws against new applications of this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Cult of Destruction
entries: The cult of destruction specializes in mastery over the destructive forces of arcane magic, powerful spells, and the potency of soul shards.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The cult of destruction lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Soul Control
entries: Beginning when you choose this cult at 2nd level, each time you take force damage from a soul shard, the damage is reduced by twice the spell's level, to a minimum of 1 damage taken.

In addition, whenever you deal damage to a creature with a damaging cantrip, you can choose to spend a soul shard to add to the damage roll. When you add a soul shard to a damaging cantrip in this way, you don't take the soul shard damage, but instead the target of the cantrip takes twice the amount of dice rolled for the soul shard damage normally. The amount of soul shard damage is determined by the highest level of spells you currently have access to, and the type of damage is determined by the cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Exploding Destruction
entries: Starting at 6th level, your dread spells and soul control cantrips explode with destructive energy when they deal damage.

Whenever you deal damage with a dread spell or soul control cantrip to a target, you can choose to have the spell explode, in which case each other creature within 10 feet of the damaged target or targets suffer damage of the spells type equal to your spellcasting modifier.
A spell which deals damage multiple times can only explode once, and this feature can only affect a creature once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Harvesting Capability
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can now harvest two soul shards from enemies you kill each day, instead of one. You still gain only one soul shard on a short rest.

subclassFeature.name: Ruinous Blasts
entries: Starting at 14th level, your dread spells become so destructive that they destroy the environment around their impact.
When you successfully deal damage to a creature with any of your targeted dread spells, the first 10 feet of movement that the creature spends on it's next turn is considered difficult terrain.
In addition, your dread spells that target an area turn that area into difficult terrain until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Cult of Necromancy
entries: The cult of necromancy focuses on the cosmic forces of life, death, and undeath. Necromancers are obsessed with harnessing the power to steal the life force of other creatures for their own gain and survival, and turning it into magic they can manipulate.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The cult of necromancy lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

subclassFeature.name: Life Harvester
entries: Beginning when you choose this cult at 2nd level, you gain the ability to reap life energy from creatures you kill or have damaged on the same round they die on with your spells. Once per turn when you do so, you regain hit points equal to three times the spell's level that you cast. You don't gain this benefit for killing constructs or undead. You can only regain as many hit points as the target creatures maximum hit points are.

subclassFeature.name: Corpse Explosion
entries: Beginning when you choose this cult at 2nd level, you can cause the corpses of deceased creatures to partly explode, shooting out flesh, bones and organs at all targets next to the corpse. This ability does not work on constructs.

If a corpse is within line of sight and 60 feet of you, you can cause a corpse to explode either as an action or a reaction. You can use this ability as an action on your turn, or as a reaction immediately after a creature dies outside of your turn.

Each creature within 5 feet of the exploding corpse must make a Dexterity saving throw against your warlock spell save DC. On a failed save, the affected targets take {@dice 1d10} force damage, or half as much damage on a successful one.
The damage of this ability increases to {@dice 2d10} at 5th level, {@dice 3d10} at 11th level, and {@dice 4d10} at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Necrotic Fortification
entries: Starting at 6th level, your powers of self sustenance grant you the ability to replenish your life force to a higher degree than normal.

Whenever you heal yourself with a spell or feature that grants you hit points exceeding your total hit point maximum, the overhealing is converted into temporary hit points. The amount of temporary hit points gained from this feature can only give you at most an amount equal to what your warlock level is.
The temporary hit points gained from Necrotic Fortification stacks with any existing temporary hit points you have from this source, or any other source, but only up to the earlier mentioned limit.

If you have an amount of temporary hit points below your warlock level, and you gain temporary hit points from Necrotic Fortification, you can only gain an amount of them that brings you equal to your warlock level. If you have temporary hit points exceeding your warlock level, you do not gain any temporary hit points from this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Army of the Dead
entries: At 10th level, you learn the {@spell Danse Macabre|xge} spell if you do not already know it. If you already know the spell, you can learn another warlock spell instead, but regardless this spell does not count towards your maximum spells known.
You can use this feature to cast Danse Macabre once per long rest without expending a spell slot, and you can also cast the spell using soul shards.

subclassFeature.name: Undying
entries: Starting at 14th level, your necromantic powers can raise those that are at deaths door.
Whenever you are reduced to below 0 hit points, each successful death saving throw you make is treated as a natural 20.
In addition, whenever a creature within 30 feet of you rolls a successful death saving throw, you can use your reaction to cause that death saving throw to be treated as a natural 20.

subclassFeature.name: School of the Manticore
entries: The school of the manticore focuses on the utilization and improvement of the products of slayer alchemy, as well as their improved toxicity levels. The manticore schools members find that success in combat and hunting comes from good preparation with the right consumables for the job.

subclassFeature.name: Heightened Tolerance
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you choose this subclass, your body has developed and mutated to such an extent that it surpasses even normal slayer levels of tolerance towards toxicity. Your toxicity limit is increased by 2, and you learn two additional Slayer Alchemy formulae.
You can now also consume products of your Slayer Alchemy feature even if they would bring you over your toxicity limit, at the cost of being increasingly vulnerable to damage.

When you consume slayer alchemy items exceeding your toxicity limit, each point you exceed your toxicity limit with causes you to take 1 additional damage each time you suffer damage from any source. You can not exceed your toxicity limit by more than what your current slayer level is at the time. If and when your toxicity level goes down, your damage vulnerability also decreases accordingly.

subclassFeature.name: Undying Mutant
entries: Starting at 9th level, your venomous blood can fortify you even against lethal damage. When you suffer damage that would reduce you to below 1 hit point, the toxicity in your veins can rush through and cauterize the wound.

If you choose to, your current toxicity level at the time can negate damage that would bring you below 1 hit point, so that every 1 toxicity prevents 1 damage, up to a maximum amount equal to your current toxicity level. Each point of toxicity that prevents damage when this happens is then lost. If you have any active mutagens when this occurs, and the toxicity you lose would bring you below what is currently being caused by a mutagen, then the effects of that mutagen ends.
You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Venomous Blades
entries: Starting at 13th level, your toxicity makes even your weapons venomous. When you are at or above your toxicity limit, your weapon attacks deal an additional {@dice 1d6} poison damage.

subclassFeature.name: Mutated Deviant
entries: At 17th level, your body becomes so malleable that you can permanently alter yourself for the better.
Choose one slayer {@filter mutagen|optionalfeatures|feature type=sm} that you have access to. You gain the effects of that mutagen permanently, without the toxicity cost or the negative side effects.

subclassFeature.name: School of the Griffon
entries: The school of the griffon specializes in the use and mastery of signs and other magic. Although slayers typically only use very basic arcane magic, the griffon school's members train to further their abilities beyond just that.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Repertoire
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you choose this subclass, your education in the arcane arts grants you an increased arsenal of low level magic. If any spells require a spell save DC or spell attack rolls, Wisdom is your spellcasting modifier. You can use your slayer medallion as a spellcasting focus for these spells.
You can learn cantrips and 1st-level spells at 3rd level, 2nd-level spells at 5th level, and 3rd-level spells at 9th level.

Casting a cantrip costs no vigor points, a 1st-level spell costs 3 vigor points, a 2nd-level spell costs 4 vigor points, and a 3rd-level spell costs 6 vigor points. These spells can be upcast to higher levels.
When you choose this subclass, you learn one additional sign or cantrip, and one spell. Your maximum vigor points are also increased by 3.

You also now learn one additional spell each time you gain a level in this class, and each time you would learn a sign, you can choose to learn a cantrip instead. You also continue learning signs or cantrips past 10th level as well, learning one every even level.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Sign Magic
entries: Starting at 9th level, all of your {@filter signs|optionalfeatures|feature type=ss}, and each of their versions become more potent:
{@bold {@italic Barrier.}} Now also grants resistance to acid, force, thunder, and lightning damage as well.
{@bold {@italic Blast.}} The range of the sign is increased by 15 feet, and the pushback distance is increased by 5 feet.
{@bold {@italic Hone.}} The reach of your honed weapon attacks is increased by 5 feet.
{@bold {@italic Ignite.}} The flames now spread around corners, so that affected creatures do not benefit from 1/2 or 3/4 cover.
{@bold {@italic Manipulate.}} The range of the sign is increased by 30 feet.
{@bold {@italic Ring.}} The radius of the ring is increased by 5 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Supercharge
entries: Starting at 13th level, you can now cast the basic versions of your basic signs without expending any vigor points.

In addition, you can now supercharge all of your signs to deal extra damage by spending additional vigor points when casting a sign. When casting any sign, you can spend up to 5 additional vigor points to supercharge the sign. Each additional vigor point used gives the sign {@dice 1d6} extra damage. The supercharged sign deals this damage when varying circumstances are met, based on the sign:

{@bold {@italic Barrier.}} When a creatures attack is resisted by the barrier for the first time for that enemy, they must make a Constitution saving throw, suffering the supercharge damage on a failed save, and half as much on a success. The damage is thunder damage.

{@bold {@italic Blast.}} When a creature makes a saving throw against your blast, they suffer the additional supercharge damage on a failed save, and half as much on a success. The damage is force damage.
{@bold {@italic Hone.}} If a weapon attack affected by your Hone hits a target, they suffer the additional supercharge damage, which is determined by the weapons damage type.
{@bold {@italic Ignite.}} The supercharge damage of ignite, which is fire, is added to the damage roll for the sign.
{@bold {@italic Manipulate.}} When a creature fails the saving throw against your manipulate, they suffer the additional supercharge damage, which is psychic damage.
{@bold {@italic Ring.}} When an enemy fails the saving throw against your ring, they suffer the supercharge damage, which is lightning damage.

subclassFeature.name: Hastened Reflexes
entries: At 17th level, you learn a new unique sign, called {@optfeature Expediate|farover}. This sign does not count toward your total Signs Known. The Expediate sign only has a basic version, and always costs 10 vigor points, not benefiting from your Supercharge feature.

subclassFeature.name: School of the Bear
entries: The school of the bear is the school that prefers a more practical and straightforward approach in combat, focusing on martial ability and skill.

subclassFeature.name: Weapon Prowess
entries: When you select the School of the Bear at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@table Farover Weapons|farover|Tactical Weapons} (Blowguns, Bolas, Hand Crossbows, and Nets).

In addition, when you roll a 1 or 2 on a damage die for an attack you make with a melee weapon that you are wielding with two hands, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1 or a 2.

subclassFeature.name: Martial Reflexes
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you choose this subclass, your extensive training in melee combat allows you to utilize your reflexes to perform new feats. You can expend vigor points for one of the following effects:

items: When another creature hits you with either a melee weapon attack, or a ranged weapon attack with a physical arrow or bolt, you can use your reaction, expending {@bold 1} vigor point, to use your melee weapon to parry the incoming attack, adding +2 to your AC against that attack.

When another creature misses you with a melee attack with a weapon, you can use your reaction, expending {@bold 1} vigor point, to attempt to disarm the creature. Make a melee weapon attack, contested by the target's {@skill Athletics} check or {@skill Acrobatics} check. If you win, the target drops the weapon it missed you with.

You can use a bonus action on your turn, expending {@bold 2} vigor points, to make a ranged attack with either a weapon that has the thrown property, or a hand crossbow. You can draw the weapon as part of making this attack, and you do not have disadvantage on this attack caused by being within 5 feet of a hostile creature.

subclassFeature.name: Sharpened Technique
entries: Starting at 9th level, each version of the {@optfeature Hone|farover} sign is now a free action for you, instead of a bonus action. You can only cast Hone once per turn. The vigor point costs of the sign remain the same.

subclassFeature.name: Cruel Onslaught
entries: Starting at 13th level, you learn the formula for the {@optfeature Cruelty|farover|Cruelty mutagen}. This formula does not count towards your total Slayer Alchemy formulae known.

subclassFeature.name: Devastating Strikes
entries: Starting at 17th level, you learn two new devastating attack action options.
Using one of these special attacks takes up your entire action, and they are based on the type of weapon you are wielding.

entries.name: Hemorrhage
entries: You can make this attack only if you are wielding a weapon with the Versatile property.

You make a well placed weapon attack with advantage at a weak spot of your target. If the attack hits, the weapons damage dice is doubled, and the target will bleed for {@dice 1d4} rounds, taking an additional {@dice 1d8} damage at the start of each of it's turns for the duration.

entries.name: Rend
entries: You can make this attack only if you are wielding a weapon with the Heavy property.

You make a powerful attack with advantage, bringing your weapon down from great height. If the attack hits, the weapons damage dice is doubled, and the target takes additional weapon damage equal to twice the amount by how much the attack roll passed the targets armor class.

subclassFeature.name: School of the Viper
entries: The school of the viper is a less known school of slayers, who specialize specifically on stealth and assassination, often times taking on contracts for humanoids rather than monsters. Slayers from the school of the viper typically dual wield smaller weapons called the twin fangs, as opposed to the traditional single two-handed weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Twin Fangs Fighting Style
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you select this subclass, your intensive training in the quick and unpredictable fighting style of the viper slayers begins to yield results, granting you the benefits of this exceptional fighting style:

items: When you engage in two-weapon fighting, you can add your ability modifier to the damage of your off-hand attack.
You can perform the somatic components of your slayer signs even while wielding a weapon in the same hand.
When you attack a creature that is considered surprised, you can expend 1 vigor point to deal an additional {@dice 2d4} weapon damage to the target.
You gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill if you don't already have it.

subclassFeature.name: Viper's Mark
entries: At 9th level, you can silently mark a target for death as your designated prey. As a bonus action, choose one creature you can see within 120 feet of you. The target is marked for 1 minute. The mark ends early if the target dies, you die, or you are incapacitated. Until the mark ends, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your movement speed is doubled and your jump distance is tripled for the duration, as long as you are moving towards your marked target.
The first time you attack the target on your turn after marking it, you have advantage on attack rolls on that turn against the marked target.
Once per turn for the duration, you can deal an extra {@dice 1d8} poison damage to the marked target with a weapon attack.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Premeditated Murder
entries: At 13th level, you can craft one free {@variantrule weapon oils|farover|weapon oil} of any kind as a part of your {@classFeature slayer alchemy|Slayer|farover|3} feature during a short rest. This oil does not count towards your total craftable items.

When you apply the oil to a weapon of yours, it lasts indefinitely, or until you coat the weapon with a different oil or poison. This feature can only be active on one weapon at a time; coating an additional weapon with a weapon oil works as normal.
In addition, when a creature makes a saving throw against any consumable poison directly administered or applied by you, the creature makes the saving throw at disadvantage.

subclassFeature.name: Assiduous Duelist
entries: At 17th level, your keenly developed viper's mark reaches its full potential.
If the marked target hits you with an attack roll, you can use your reaction to roll a d6. On a 4 or higher, the attack instead misses you, regardless of its roll.
In addition, when your marked target dies, you can apply the mark to a different creature you can see within 60 feet of you, provided you aren't incapacitated.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Domain
entries: Gods of spirits, such as Felumbra, govern the souls that power all mortal creatures. Embodied as the moon in the sky, newly born creatures are imbued with a part of the moon which is their soul, and when they pass away the soul returns to the moon.
Clerics of the spirit domain manipulate spirits and vital life force, and they project powerful boons to assist their allies in realizing their ideals.

subclassFeature.name: Moonlit Pilgrim
entries: At 1st level, you can see in moonlight that would normally be considered dim light as if it was bright light. You can share this vision to any other creature you touch, for as long as you keep touching them.
You also innately know how long it is until dusk and dawn, and you are also always aware of the current lunar phase.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Spirit Sanctuary
entries: At 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to create a field of protective spirits for you and your allies.

As an action, you present your holy symbol, and a 20-foot radius sphere of moonlight appears at a point you can see within 60 feet. The sphere lasts for 1 minute, or until you are incapacitated or die. Whenever a creature (including you) ends its turn in the sphere, you can grant that creature one of these benefits:

items: You grant it temporary hit points equal to your cleric level.
You end one effect on it causing it to be {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Soul Tear
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use your Channel Divinity to momentarily force the soul out of an enemy creature.

As an action, an enemy you can see within 30 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, its soul is ripped out of its body to an unoccupied location of your choice within 30 feet of both the target and you. Constructs, fiends, and undead are unaffected. The soul is the same size as the target, and it occupies an equally large area. If no unoccupied space large enough is available, the ability fails. The spirit remains for 1 minute, but the target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on a success and returning the spirit to its body.

The spirit uses the same statistics as the target creature, and for most intents and purposes is a duplicate of the target creature, although it does not have its own turn, and it can not take any actions. The other difference is that the spirit does not have its own hit points, but rather is linked to the hit points of the creature it was ripped from. When the spirit would take damage, the original creature takes the damage instead. Both the spirit and the original creature can thus be damaged, but the original creature takes the damage for both.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: Starting at 8th level, you are blessed with divine might in battle. When a creature takes damage from one of your cantrips or weapon attacks, you can also deal {@dice 1d8} radiant damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Shroud of Spirits
entries: At 17th level, the spiritual magic of your Spirit Sanctuary gains additional benefits:

items: Temporary hit points granted to a creature equals {@dice 1d10} plus your cleric level.
You can also end of effect on a creature causing it to be {@condition paralyzed}.

subclassFeature.name: Time Domain
entries: Clerics who are a part of the time domain serve gods who control the flow of time and the fate of events and creatures in the planes of existence. Gods of fate and time, such as Tempos, cause the changing of seasons, and imbues creatures with a sense of purpose. Clerics of the time domain thus follow and spread these ideals in their ways and teachings, imparting meaning and regularity to followers of the faith.

subclassFeature.name: Scholar of Fate
entries: At 1st level, you are astutely aware of ongoing events which grants you advantage on initiative rolls.
You also gain proficiency in the {@skill History} and {@skill Religion} skills.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Delay Time
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your Channel Divinity to momentarily alter the flow of time for yourself and act faster than normally possible.

On your turn, you can use your Channel Divinity to take one additional action. You can use this additional action to do anything you normally could except cast a spell of 1st-level or higher with a casting time of 1 action. You may use it to cast a second spell on your turn if that spell has a casting time of 1 bonus action, or if it's a cantrip.
You can only use this feature once per turn.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Assign Fate
entries: At 6th level, you can use your Channel Divinity to determine a creatures upcoming fate in battle. You can either assign a fortuitous fate to an ally, or an unfortunate one to an enemy.

items: {@bold {@italic Fortuitous Fate.}} When you target yourself or an allied creature with a spell of 1st-level or higher on your turn, you can use your Channel Divinity as a bonus action to grant that creature advantage on all of its ability checks and attack rolls it makes until the end of its next turn.

{@bold {@italic Unfortunate Fate.}} When you target an enemy creature with a spell of 1st-level or higher on your turn, you can use your Channel Divinity as a bonus action to cause that creature to have disadvantage on all of its ability checks and attack rolls it makes until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Blessed Strikes
entries: Starting at 8th level, you are blessed with divine might in battle. When a creature takes damage from one of your cantrips or weapon attacks, you can also deal {@dice 1d8} radiant damage to that creature. Once you deal this damage, you can't use this feature again until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Predestined Purpose
entries: At 17th level, you gain access to the {@spell Time Stop} and {@spell Foresight} spells. Your body also ceases to age, which means you do not suffer the {@table aging effects|farover|negative effects of old age}, and you can not die of old age.

Additionally, when a creature you can see makes an attack roll against you, you can use your reaction to force the creature to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the attack misses.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

feat.name: Arcane Adept
entries: You have a natural talent for magic and have honed your abilities to a high degree. You gain the following benefits:

items: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Arcana} skill, or expertise if you already have proficiency in {@skill Arcana}.
Once per long rest, you can immediately regain one spell slot of your choice. The slot cannot be of the highest level you can cast.
Once per day, when you miss with a spell attack roll, you can choose to reroll it.

feat.name: Armor Expert
entries: Great physical fortitude and strength has made wearing armor easier for you. You gain the following benefits:

items: Any armor you wear is less of a burden for you. While wearing a set of armor, you treat the armor as if it weighs less in pounds equal to your Strength score (to a minimum of 1 pound), for the purposes of carrying capacity.

feat.name: Blood Magic
entries: You have learned the forbidden secrets of Blood Magic, invented long ago by the Necromancer Cult of the Warlocks. You gain the following benefit:

items: Instead of spending a spell slot to cast a spell, you can spend and cause yourself one of your hit die of damage per level of the spell. If you are multi-classed, you may chooose which hit die, but it must be from a spellcasting class. Wounding yourself counts as the somatic component of the spell you are casting, and you must be holding a weapon that deals slashing or piercing damage (unless you can readily cut yourself on something). If you have resistance to slashing or piercing damage, your resistance doesn't function against the damage you cause yourself when using Blood Magic.

feat.name: Charger
entries: When you take the special {@action Charge|farover} action, you can do one of the following things:

items: Add an extra +10 to the damage of the charge attack.
Instead of making a melee weapon attack, you can attempt to shove the creature. If you do so, you can shove it 10 feet.

feat.name: Counter Striker
entries: You have practiced dealing with spellcasters in the heat of battle, from which you have learned how to interrupt their process of spellcasting. You gain the following benefit:

items: When a creature within reach of a melee weapon you are holding casts a spell, you can use your reaction to make a melee weapon attack against that creature. This attack deals damage as normal, but it can also interrupt the spell from being cast. Make an ability check using the ability you used for the weapon attack roll. The base DC equals 10 + the spell's level. Additionally, the difference between your level and the target creature's level is applied to the DC, which can raise or lower the DC, depending on the difference. On a success, the creature's spell fails and has no effect.

feat.name: Crafty Duelist
entries: Your quick hands allow you to attempt to disarm targets with speed rather than brute force. You gain the following benefits:

items: When attempting to disarm enemy creatures, you can roll a Sleight of Hand skill check in place of the normal weapon attack roll. If you would normally have advantage on an attack roll against the target, you make the Sleight of Hand roll at advantage.

feat.name: Enhanced Reflexes
entries: Your reflexes are honed to a razor's edge. You gain the following benefits:

items: At the start of a combat, after all initiatives have been rolled but before anyone has acted, you may switch places in the initiative order with another creature that you can see, as long as that creature is not at the top of the initiative order. You may not use this feature again until you have completed a short or long rest.

feat.name: Feisty Combatant
entries: Your rhetorical skills can allow you to shift the tide of battle by manipulating enemies. You gain the following benefits:

items: As an action, you can attempt to taunt an enemy that can hear and understand you within 60 feet into attacking you. Make a Persuasion check, and the target must make a contested Wisdom saving throw. If you win, the target creature has disadvantage on attack rolls against any other creature than you until the end of its next turn.

feat.name: Great Weapon Master
entries: You've learned to put the weight of a weapon to your advantage, letting its momentum empower your strikes. You gain the following benefits:

items: On your turn, when you score a natural 20 critical hit with a melee weapon or reduce a creature to 0 hit points with one, you can make one melee weapon attack as a bonus action.
Before you make a melee attack with a heavy weapon that you are proficient with, you can choose to take a -5 penalty to the attack roll. If the attack hits, you add +5 to the attack's damage.

feat.name: Insightful Precision
entries: Your keen eye in combat allows you to spot the weak spots of your enemies. You gain the following benefits:

items: Before making an attack roll with either a Finesse or ranged weapon, you can choose to make an Insight check as a bonus action. If the Insight check passes the targets AC, the next Finesse or ranged weapon attack roll you make against the target on the same turn is made at advantage, and if the attack hits, the target also suffers additional weapon damage equal to half your Insight modifier (rounded down). Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

feat.name: Oracle
entries: Glimpses of the future begin to press in on your awareness, allowing you to potentially change fate. You gain the following benefits:

items: When you finish a long rest, you can decide to roll a d20. Record the number rolled, and then assign this number to either yourself, or a nearby willing creature. The next time the assigned creature rolls that number on a d20, they must reroll the d20. This effect happens only once. When you finish a long rest, the creature with the foretelling roll loses it if it has not yet been used.

feat.name: Poisonous
entries: Something has inured you to poison, nay more than inured you. You are poison itself... You gain the following benefits:

items: You gain resistance to poison damage.
You have advantage on saving throws against poison.

As a bonus action, you may lick a weapon. For the next minute, that weapon does an additional point of poison damage whenever it deals damage. You may not lick another weapon until you have completed a short or long rest.

feat.name: Powerful Attacks
entries: Extensive weapons training has given you great physical power, granting you the following benefits:

items: When attacking with a weapon that has the versatile property in one hand, you may roll damage as if you were holding it in both hands.
You have advantage on Strength checks to maintain possession of your weapons against disarming effects.

entries: There are worse things than dying, Bill. I wake up most mornings and I want it. I hope for it.

items: You can make one {@action Opportunity Attack} per round without using your reaction.

feat.name: Restful Sleeper
entries: You are one of the gifted people able to sleep well no matter the conditions. You gain the following benefits:

items: If you finish a short rest without expending hit dice, you regain an amount of hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

feat.name: Second Chance
entries: Fortune favors you when someone tries to strike you. You gain the following benefits:

items: When a creature you can see hits you with an attack roll, you can use your reaction to force that creature to reroll. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

feat.name: Sharpshooter
entries: You have mastered ranged weapons and can make shots that others find impossible. You gain the following benefits:

items: Your ranged weapon attacks ignore half cover and three-quarters cover.
Before you make an attack with a ranged weapon that you are proficient with, you can choose to take a -5 penalty to the attack roll. If the attack hits, you add +5 to the attack's damage.

feat.name: Thick Build
entries: You have been well fed and you have maintained your mass during your life, granting you the following benefits:

items: When any attack or effect would either shove you or knock you prone, you have advantage on any Constitution or Strength saving throws to stand your ground.

feat.name: Unspoken
entries: You have extensive experience conveying emotions and ideas through expressions and gestures, granting you the following benefits:

items: You can convey simple ideas or emotions limited to one word through subtle facial expressions or signs to anyone who can see you, and they understand the meaning as long as they have an Intelligence score of at least 6. The time it takes to do so is one round.
Even when in a form in which you cannot naturally speak (such as an animal), you are able to speak normally in any language you know.

feat.name: War Caster
entries: You have practiced casting spells in the midst of combat, learning techniques that grant you the following benefits:

items: You have advantage on Constitution saving throws that you make to maintain your concentration on a spell when you take damage.
You can perform the somatic components of spells even when you have weapons or a shield in one or both hands.

feat.name: Weapon Specialist
entries: Extensive training has granted you mastery with one type of weapon:

items: Choose one weapon with which you are proficient. You gain a +1 bonus on all attack rolls and a +1 bonus on all damage rolls you make with that weapon. You may choose to gain advantage on an attack roll you make with that weapon; you may not gain advantage from this feat again until you have completed a short or long rest.

entries: You can select this feat multiple times, and if you choose the same weapon, you are granted an extra use of this feature per short rest when giving yourself advantage on an attack roll you make with the specialized weapon.

entries.name: Age
entries: Stormborn live roughly as long as humans, and reach adulthood at the same point as well.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most Stormborn are Chaotic.

entries.name: Size
entries: Stormborn are on average slightly taller than normal humans, typically standing from 5'7'' all the way to 7 feet. Your size is Medium.

entries.name: Harsh Training
entries: You have proficiency in the Athletics skill.

entries.name: Damage Resistance
entries: You have resistance to either lightning or thunder damage (your choice).

entries.name: Gift of the Storm
entries: You know the {@spell Thunderclap|xge} cantrip.

If the prevalent weather in your area is a thunderstorm, you can cast the {@spell Thunderwave} spell once with this trait as a bonus action; you regain the ability to cast it when you finish a long rest. The damage of this spell increases by 1d8 each time you reach a level where you would unlock higher level spells as a full spellcaster.
Strength is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one extra language of your choice.

spell.name: Aegis of Shadows
entries: A protective aura of shadows forms around you, and stays with you until the spell ends. You gain {@dice 5d6} temporary hit points. While you have these temporary hit points and the spell is active, you have advantage on Constitution saving throws.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, the amount of temporary hit points is increased by {@dice 2d6} for each slot level above 3rd.
