Any creatures within 20 feet of that point must make a Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} and pushed 10 feet away from it.
Upon emerging, the purple worm lays down before you and opens its maw. Targets can climb inside where they are enclosed in an impervious hemispherical dome of force.

Once targets are loaded into the purple worm, nothing—-not physical objects, energy, or other spell effects-—can pass through the barrier, in or out, though targets in the sphere can breathe there. The hemisphere is immune to all damage, and creatures and objects inside can’t be damaged by attacks or effects originating from outside, nor can a target inside the hemisphere damage anything outside it. The atmosphere inside the dome is comfortable and dry regardless of conditions outside it.

The purple worm waits until you give it a mental command to depart, at which point it dives back into the ground and travels, without need for rest or food, as directly as possible while avoiding obstacles to a destination known to you. It travels 150 miles (240 kilometers) per day.
When the purple worm reaches its destination it surfaces, the dome vanishes, and it disgorges the targets in its mouth before diving back into the depths again.

The purple worm remains {@condition charmed} by you until it has delivered you to your destination and returned to the depths, or until it is attacked at which point the charm ends, it vomits its targets in the nearest unoccupied space as soon as possible, and then retreats to safety.

spell.name: Mass Dispel
entries: A burst of antimagic explodes in a 20-foot-radius sphere at a point you choose within range, affecting each creature, object, and magical effect of your choosing.

Make an ability check using your spellcasting ability. The base DC equals 10 + a spell's level. Additionally, the difference between your level and either a target creature's level (if cast on a creature affected by a spell) or the spellcaster's level (if cast on a magical effect or object), is applied to the DC, which can raise or lower the DC, depending on the difference.
Depending on the DC's of the affected targets, any spells or magical effects that the ability check succeeds against end.

spell.name: Improved Blink
entries: Upon casting this spell, you place yourself on the border of your current plane, and the ethereal plane. Similarly to the {@spell blink} spell, this spell allows you to vanish and appear in the Ethereal Plane, but by improved means.

While the spell is active, whenever you are hit by a damaging attack, you can use your reaction to snap your fingers and vanish from your current plane of existence, appearing in the Ethereal Plane and avoiding the damage completely. At the start of your next turn, and when the spell ends if you are on the Ethereal Plane, you return to an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see within 15 feet of the space you vanished from. If no unoccupied space is available within that range, you appear in the nearest unoccupied space (chosen at random if more than one space is equally near).

While on the Ethereal Plane, you have advantage on initiative rolls. You can also see and hear the plane you originated from, which is cast in shades of gray, but you can't see anything there more than 60 feet away. You can only affect and be affected by other creatures on the Ethereal Plane. Creatures that aren't there can't perceive you or interact with you, unless they have the ability to do so.

spell.name: Audible Thoughts
entries: By a wave of your hand, you attempt to remove the separation of inner and voiced thoughts from a humanoids mind within range. The spell fails if the target does not speak any languages. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw, or be affected by the spell for a minute, unless you stop concentrating on it early.

For the duration of the spell, the target's inner thoughts going through its mind are all audibly voiced by the target out loud. Mild thoughts and ideas might be spoken in a soft tone, and powerful or angry ones might even be shouted. The target does not realize that this is happening, even though it is clearly opening its mouth and speaking. From the target's perspective, nothing is out of the ordinary and it is keeping all of its inner thoughts to itself.

The target does not realize this change in its behavior, but other people obviously do. The target receives no additional saving throws to end the effect early, unless another person even indirectly informs the target of their odd behavior. If the target is made aware of their audible thoughts by you or a third party, it can begin to repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns to end the effect.

spell.name: Rusting Grasp

components.m: an antenna from a rust monster

entries: By casting this spell, the you gain the power to destroy non-magical ferrous metals and alloys by way of corrosion at a touch. Iron and iron-based alloys such as steel, meteoric iron, mithril, and adamantite are affected, but noble metals such as gold, silver, and copper are not subject to reduction through rusting.

To corrode a metal in this way, make a melee spell attack. Any non-magical ferrous metal item or object you touch with the attack roll is destroyed if the attack roll meets or beats its AC. The AC for different substances can be found in the {@link Statistics for Objects|https://5e.tools/objects.html#generic%20object_dmg} section of the SRD (iron and steel for example have an AC of 19).

spell.name: Guidance
entries: You touch one willing creature. Once before the spell ends, the target can roll a {@dice d4} and add the number rolled to one Dexterity or Strength based ability check of its choice. It can roll the die before or after making the ability check. The spell then ends.

spell.name: Dissonant Whispers
entries: You whisper a discordant melody that only one creature of your choice within range can hear, wracking it with terrible pain. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it takes {@damage 3d6} psychic damage and must immediately use its reaction, if available, to move as far as its speed allows away from you. The creature doesn't move into obviously dangerous ground, such as a fire or a pit, and does not provoke attacks of opportunity. On a successful save, the target takes half as much damage and doesn't have to move away. A {@condition deafened} creature automatically succeeds on the save.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 3d6|1-9|1d6} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Aura of Life
entries: Life-preserving energy radiates from you in an aura with a 30-foot radius. Until the spell ends, the aura moves with you, centered on you. Each nonhostile creature in the aura (including you) has resistance to necrotic damage, and its hit point maximum can't be reduced. In addition, a nonhostile, living creature returns to 1 hit point when it starts its turn in the aura with 0 or less hit points.

spell.name: Thunder Mote
entries: You create a mote of latent magic to attach on to a creature within range. The target must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be affected by the spell. An affected creature can take an action to snuff out the mote. The mote harmlessly lasts for the duration of the spell, unless you use either a bonus action or reaction to cause it to explode, dealing {@damage 1d8} thunder damage to the target and removing the mote.

The spell creates additional motes when you reach 5th level (2 motes), 11th level (3 motes), and 17th level (4 motes). Multiple motes can be cast at one or multiple targets, with a separate saving throw for each one.

spell.name: Tasha's Caustic Brew
entries: A stream of acid emanates from you in a line 30 feet long and 5 feet wide in a direction you choose. Each creature in the line must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be covered in acid for the spell's duration or until a creature uses its action to scrape or wash the acid off itself or another creature. A creature covered in the acid takes {@damage 2d4} acid damage at start of each of its turns.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the damage increases by {@scaledamage 2d4|1-9|2d4} for each slot level above 1st.

spell.name: Intellect Fortress
entries: For the duration, you or one willing creature you can see within range has resistance to psychic damage, as well as advantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using a spell slot of 4th level or higher, you can target one additional creature for each slot level above 3rd. The creatures must be within 30 feet of each other when you target them.

spell.name: Wall of Stone
entries: A nonmagical wall of solid stone springs into existence at a point you choose within range. The wall is 6 inches thick and is composed of ten 10-foot-by-10-foot panels. Each panel must be contiguous with at least one other panel.

If the wall cuts through a creature's space when it appears, the creature is pushed to one side of the wall (your choice). If a creature would be surrounded on all sides by the wall (or the wall and another solid surface), that creature can make a Dexterity saving throw. On a success, it can use its reaction to move up to its speed so that it is no longer enclosed by the wall.

The wall can have any shape you desire, though it can't occupy the same space as a creature or object. The wall doesn't need to be vertical or rest on any firm foundation. It must, however, merge with and be solidly supported by existing stone. Thus, you can use this spell to bridge a chasm or create a ramp.
If you create a span greater than 20 feet in length, you must halve the size of each panel to create supports. You can crudely shape the wall to create crenellations, battlements, and so on.

The wall is an object made of stone that can be damaged and thus breached. Each panel has AC 15 and 30 hit points. Reducing a panel to 0 hit points destroys it and might cause connected panels to collapse at the DM's discretion.
If you maintain your {@status concentration} on this spell for its whole duration, the wall becomes permanent and can't be dispelled. Otherwise, the wall disappears when the spell ends.

spell.name: Plant Growth
entries: This spell channels vitality into plants within a specific area. There are two possible uses for the spell, granting either immediate or long-term benefits.

If you cast this spell for 1 minute, choose a point within range. All normal plants in a 100-foot radius centered on that point become thick and overgrown. A creature moving through the area must spend 4 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves.
You can exclude one or more areas of any size within the spell's area from being affected.

If you cast this spell over 8 hours, you enrich the land. All plants in a half-mile radius centered on a point within range become enriched for 1 year. The plants yield twice the normal amount of food when harvested.

spell.name: Lesser Restoration

m.text: diamond dust worth at least 30 gp, which the spell consumes

entries: You touch a creature and grant it one of the following effects:

items: Cure some form of lingering injury, as per the lingering injury table.
End either one disease or one condition afflicting it. The condition can be {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, or {@condition poisoned}
Reduce the targets {@condition exhaustion} level by one.
When you fall below 25% hit points, you become wounded.
When you are wounded, you gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
This {@condition exhaustion} level can only be lost by removing the wounded condition, which is done by healing to at least 25% hit points.

disease.name: Cancer
entries: Cancer is an almost incurable disease that can be contracted from heavy radiant damage, or simply from old age. The {@spell Wish} spell is the only known way to cure cancer.
Cancer has four stages, and when it first developes, it begins with the first stage. A creature suffers the effects of its current stage, as well as all lower levels.

After every year that passes since developing cancer, an affected character must succeed on a DC 20 Constitution saving throw, or the cancer develops to the next stage. Once the fourth stage has passed, the character dies.

items: {@bold {@italic First Stage.}} During the first stage of cancer, you experience weight loss, skin irregularities, and coughing. Additionally, you have disadvantage on Constitution ability checks, and your movement speed is reduced by 5.

{@bold {@italic Second Stage.}} During the second stage, you experience yellowing of your skin and eyes, nausea, and vomiting. Additionally, you now permanently have one stack of {@condition exhaustion} that can not be removed, and all your attributes are lowered by 1.

{@bold {@italic Third Stage.}} During the third stage, you experience loss of appetite, persistent pain, and difficulty breathing. Additionally, you now permanently have two stacks of {@condition exhaustion} that can not be removed, and all your attributes are lowered by an additional 1.

{@bold {@italic Fourth Stage.}} During the fourth stage, you experience severe, persistent pain, seizures and convulsions, and significant fatigue. Additionally, you now permanently have three stacks of {@condition exhaustion} that can not be removed, and all your attributes are lowered by an additional 2.

variantrule.name: Weapon Oils
entries: Weapon oils are specialized chemical compounds that are effective against different types of creatures. One oil exists for every creature type (humanoid, beast, dragon, etc.), and they all have the same effect on their target. Weapon oil vials can be bought in most major towns/cities, and they cost 40g per dose, weigh 1 lb, and they last for either 5 successful weapon attacks or 24 hours, dealing 1d4 extra damage to the type of creature its meant for. Coating a weapon in oil is an action.
Characters with a proficiency with the {@item Poisoner's Kit|phb} can craft weapon oils for a cheaper price.

variantrule.name: Negative Temporary Hit Points
entries: Some conditions and special abilities can confer negative temporary hit points to a creature. Negative Temporary hit points aren't actual hit points nor are they damage. They represent some lasting wound or a staggering hit.

When you have negative temporary hit points and receive healing or normal temporary hit points, the negative temporary hit points are lost first, and any leftover healing or points carries over to your normal hit points. For example, if you have -5 temporary hit points and you regain 8 hit points, you lose the negative temporary hit points and then heal 3 hit points. Alternatively if you have -5 temporary hit points and are given 5 temporary hit points you now would have 0 temporary hit points.
Because negative temporary hit points are separate from your actual hit points, they can be less than 0. A character can, therefore, be at 0 hit points and receive negative temporary hit points.

Negative temporary hit points can't be added together with other negative temporary hit points. If you have negative temporary hit points and receive more of them, you retain the lower amount. For example, if a spell grants you -12 temporary hit points when you already have -10, you now have -12, and not -22 or -10.

If you have 0 hit points, receiving negative temporary hit points can absorb healing directed at you while you're in that state, but only true healing that exceeds the amount will stabilize you. Unless a feature that grants you negative temporary hit points has a duration, they last until they're depleted or you finish a short or long rest.

variantrule.name: Spell Scrolls
entries: Any character can attempt to use a spell scroll. Using a spell scroll is always an action, regardless of the spell. A class with current access to the spell in the scroll can use the scroll without any skill checks.

If the scroll is of a spell of a higher level than what the spellcaster can cast, or if the spell is one that the spellcaster's class doesn't have access to, they must make an ability check using their spellcasting ability with their proficiency modifier added against the DC.
Non-spellcasting characters can attempt to use a scroll with a flat Intelligence check against the DC.
If a character uses or fails to use a spell scroll, they can not use one again for 1 hour, and the scroll is consumed. A character can only have the effects of one scroll active at a time.
Spell scrolls use the spell save DC's and modifiers of the character who created the scroll. Learning spells from a spell scroll is not possible.

{@bold {@italic Making Spell Scrolls.}} Scribing a spell scroll requires that spell to be prepared, and proficiency in {@skill Arcana}. Any full spellcaster meeting these requirements can scribe spell scrolls. Doing so takes {@dice 1d4} days per spell level.

item.name: Slayer Medallion
entries: A slayer medallion is a magical silver amulet shaped like the symbol of the school a slayer belongs to.
A slayer medallion serves as the spellcasting focus that slayers use for their {@filter signs|optionalfeatures|feature type=ss}.

item.name: Cottage
entries: A single-room wooden building, consisting of the most primitive construction of wood.

item.name: Small House
entries: A small wooden three-room house, or component of a larger building.

item.name: Large Building
entries: A wooden building, measuring 30 feet wide, 40 feet long, and two stories, suitable for a tavern or farmhouse.

table.name: Aging Effects
intro: Every humanoid creature ages with time, and reaches new age classes as explained below. The natural lifespan of a creature is, depending on their race, a low flat amount plus a variable dice roll, resulting on average with a base venerable age. Only the DM knows this number. Characters living their final natural years will know their end is soon upon them.
{@bold {@italic Cumulative Effects}}: Each time a character reaches a new age class, apply the following cumulative effect to the characters stats: -1 to Con; -1 to Str/Dex; +1 to Int/Wis

table.name: Sunder Table
intro: When rolling on the Sunder table, type in the following command on Roll20, and then apply the result to the target of your critical hit:
rows: You go first on the next round of initiative.
You go first on the next round of initiative.
Your target goes last on the next round of initiative.
Your target goes last on the next round of initiative.
You can push your target back 5 feet.
You can push your target back 5 feet.
Your target is stunned until it takes damage or until the start of it's next turn.
Your target is stunned until it takes damage or until the start of it's next turn.
Your targets right leg is injured, -10 movement speed until a short rest.
Your targets left leg is injured, -10 movement speed until a short rest.
Your targets chest is injured, causing them to gain 1 level of exhaustion.
Your targets offhand is injured, causing them to have disadvantage on everything done with it until a short rest.
Your targets mainhand is injured, causing them to have disadvantage on everything done with it until a short rest.
You make a perfect attack at a weak point, rolling 1 additional weapon damage die.

table.name: Schizophrenic Behavior Table
rows: If an ally of yours is unconscious, you will do everything in your power to preferably heal, or at least stabilize them. If they die, you will surely die too.
If you have the capability of killing an enemy of yours, you will always do it. You take no prisoners nor leave any enemies alive. They will do the same to you given the chance.
You will not step into any area with a large group of people, such as a tavern, marketplace, or busy town. They are all conspiring against you.
You will not walk in front of anyone, nor stand with your back turned to anyone for more than a moment. If they want to kill you, you will want to at least see it coming.
You will not tell any lies to anyone. The gods are always watching, ready to smite you.
You will do whatever anyone tells you to do that isn't obviously self-destructive. Why would you not? They surely know something you don't.

table.name: Farover Armor and Shields
intro: While a character is wearing {@bold {@italic medium armor}}, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage they take is reduced by {@bold 1}.
While a character is wearing {@bold {@italic heavy armor}}, bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage they take is reduced by {@bold 2}.

optionalfeature.name: Brace
entries: As a bonus action, you can ready an attack. Choose a creature you can see that is at least 20 feet away from you. If that creature moves within your weapon's reach on its next turn, you can make a melee attack against it with your braced weapon as a reaction. You can't use this ability if the creature used the {@action Disengage|phb} action before moving.

optionalfeature.name: Bleed
entries: Critical hits scored deal extra damage at the start of the creature's next turn equal to the modifier of the ability score used to make the attack.

optionalfeature.name: Cleave
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points, any excess damage can carry over to another creature within your reach, if the original attack roll hits them.

optionalfeature.name: Nonlethal
entries: You can cause a target to fall unconscious with a melee attack if you choose to, instead of it outright dying or bleeding out.

optionalfeature.name: Parry
entries: As a reaction to being hit by a melee attack with a weapon, you can reduce Bludgeoning, Piercing or Slashing damage taken by your proficiency bonus.

optionalfeature.name: Seize
entries: Immediately after you hit a creature, you can attempt to grapple it with the weapon as a bonus action. If you grapple a creature with a Seize weapon, you can't make attacks with the weapon, and you must keep a hand on it to keep the creature grappled. The grappled creature can make a contested Athletics or Acrobatics check to free itself.

optionalfeature.name: Sunder
entries: When you roll a 20 on your attack roll against a creature, you roll an additional effect from the {@table sunder table|farover}.

optionalfeature.name: Wallop
entries: When you roll a 20 on your attack roll against a size Large or smaller creature, the target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be stunned until the end of their next turn, or until they take any damage. DC = 10 + your proficiency bonus.

optionalfeature.name: Charging
entries: When you take the {@action Charge|farover} action on your turn with a Charging weapon, the attack roll is made at advantage.

optionalfeature.name: Blowgun
entries: The damage of a blowgun depends on your exhalation power and lung capacity, meaning you can add your Constitution modifier to the damage rolls. Additionally, when you are hidden from a creature and you attack it with a blowgun, making the attack doesn’t reveal your position. Finally, when you hit with a blowgun with a dart that has poison applied to it, the target has disadvantage on saving throws against the poison.

optionalfeature.name: Bola
entries: A Large or smaller creature hit by a bola is knocked prone and grappled by it until it is freed. A bola has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to free itself or another creature within its reach. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the bola (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

optionalfeature.name: Dagger
entries: Daggers deal double damage to unconscious creatures.

optionalfeature.name: Flail/Heavy Flail
entries: You can make a grapple attack with a flail in your hand. If you grapple a creature with a flail, you can't make attacks with it, and you must keep a hand on the flail to keep the creature grappled. As usual, the grappled creature can make a contested Athletics or Acrobatics check to free themselves.

optionalfeature.name: Greatbow
entries: Greatbows take both great strength and accuracy to wield effectively. The arrows shot from the greatbow are powerful, but the bow itself is so large, that it is impractical. Greatbows use your Strength modifier for attack rolls, and attack rolls with the greatbow are made at disadvantage. Greatbows use both your Strength and Dexterity modifier for damage rolls.
Greatbows have a minimum Strength requirement of 13.

optionalfeature.name: Lance
entries: You have disadvantage when you use a lance to attack a target within 5 feet of you. Also, a lance requires two hands to wield when you aren't mounted.

optionalfeature.name: Net
entries: A Large or smaller creature hit by a net is restrained until it is freed. A net has no effect on creatures that are formless, or creatures that are Huge or larger. A creature can use its action to make a DC 10 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Dealing 5 slashing damage to the net (AC 10) also frees the creature without harming it, ending the effect and destroying the net.

optionalfeature.name: Light Shield
entries: {@bold {@italic Block}}. When another creature hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to raise your light shield and add +3 to your AC against that attack.
A light shield can be equipped or unequipped with a free item interaction, instead of an action.

optionalfeature.name: Heavy Shield
entries: {@bold {@italic Block}}. When another creature hits either you or an ally of yours within 5 ft. of you with either a melee attack or a ranged weapon attack, you can use your reaction to raise your heavy shield and add +2 to either your AC or your ally's AC against that attack.

optionalfeature.name: Barrier
entries: As a bonus action, or as a reaction when you are hit by a weapon attack, you draw the sign of Barrier with your fingers in the air, and a protective shield of static energy appears around you. Until the start of your next turn, the shield grants you resistance against the first time you take bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage.

{@bold {@italic Enhanced Barrier}}. When you cast the enhanced version of this sign, the barrier also reduces the damage you take the first time you take bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage by an amount equal to your proficiency modifier.

{@bold {@italic Superior Barrier}}. When you cast the superior version of this sign, the barrier lasts until the beginning of your next turn, granting resistance and damage reduction against all bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage until then.

optionalfeature.name: Blast
entries: As a bonus action, you extend your hand outwards, arranging your fingers in the formation of Blast, and unleash a telekinetic shockwave. You can choose to attempt to knock creatures prone, or push them away. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must succeed on a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, they are either pushed back 10 feet, or knocked prone.

{@bold {@italic Enhanced Blast}}. When you cast the enhanced version of this sign, creatures who fail the saving throw are subjected to both of the effects of the sign, knocking them prone and pushing them back.

{@bold {@italic Superior Blast}}. When you cast the superior version of this sign, the area of the sign becomes a radius centered on you with the same range, instead of a cone. You can also designate any number of creatures you can see to be unaffected by it. In addition, any creature hit by your blast suffers force damage equal to twice your Wisdom modifier.

optionalfeature.name: Hone
entries: As a bonus action, you draw the sign of Hone on the hilt or guard of your weapon, and magically empower your next attack. Until the start of your next turn, you have advantage on your next weapon attack.

{@bold {@italic Enhanced Hone}}. When you cast the enhanced version of this sign, your next weapon attack until the start of your next turn will be made at advantage, and it can also hit one additional creature of your choice within your reach and within 5 feet of the primary target at disadvantage.

{@bold {@italic Superior Hone}}. When you cast the superior version of this sign, all of your weapon attacks will be made at advantage until the start of your next turn, and your next weapon attack can also hit one additional creature of your choice within your reach and within 10 feet of the primary target at disadvantage.

optionalfeature.name: Ignite
entries: As a bonus action, you extend your hand outwards, arranging your fingers in the formation of Ignite, and unleash a gush of flames. Each creature in a 15-foot cone must make a Dexterity saving throw, or take {@dice 1d6} fire damage. The damage of this sign increases by {@dice 1d6} when you reach 5th, 9th, 13th, and 17th level.
{@bold {@italic Enhanced Ignite}}. When you cast the enhanced version of this sign, the affected targets also take half as much damage on a successful save.
{@bold {@italic Superior Ignite}}. When you cast the superior version of this sign, the sign deals maximum damage, instead of rolling.

optionalfeature.name: Manipulate
entries: As a bonus action, you draw the sign of Manipulate in the air, and magically influence the mind of a creature by speaking to it. A creature that is immune to being charmed is not affected by this sign. This sign can be cast one of two ways:

items: You attempt to muddle the mind of one creature that can hear you and you can see within 60 feet. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it has disadvantage on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

You attempt to beguile a creature that can hear you and you can see within 30 feet. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, for 1 minute, you have advantage on all Charisma checks directed at the creature as long as it isn't hostile toward you.

entries: {@bold {@italic Enhanced Manipulate}}. When you cast the enhanced version of this sign, both of the two uses gain additional effects:

items: When you attempt to muddle the mind of a creature, you can target one additional creature that can hear you and you can see within 60 feet.
When you successfully beguile a creature, it also has disadvantage on any Wisdom based skill checks or Wisdom saving throws it makes for the duration, as long as it isn't hostile toward you.

entries: {@bold {@italic Superior Manipulate}}. When you cast the superior version of this sign, both of the two uses gain additional effects, in addition to the effects granted by the enhanced version:

items: When you successfully muddle the mind of a creature or creatures, you can also force one creature to use it's reaction to take one attack at a target of your choice that is within its range. The disadvantage to the targets next attack roll is not applied to this attack.

When you beguile a creature, this sign becomes a concentration spell, and it lasts for 10 minutes, but the sign can not be used on a target if it is hostile toward you, or if you or creatures that are friendly to you are fighting it. When initially casting the sign on a target successfully, you can issue a verbal command to the target, which it will follow to the best of it's ability on it's next turn. You can keep issuing commands to the target for the duration of the spell with your actions, but before each command after the initial one, the target will repeat the saving throw, ending the effect on a successful one.

entries: As a bonus action, you draw a magical ring on the ground with a 15-foot radius centered on you. The ring lasts until the start of your next turn.
For the duration of the sign, the area inside the ring is considered difficult terrain for your enemies, and all invisible creatures are revealed while they are inside.

In addition, enemies inside the ring when it is cast, and those that enter the ring later on for the first time must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, they cannot take reactions while in the ring. Leaving the area of the ring ends this effect, but re-entering it resumes them. On a successful save, a creature is unaffected by this effect from this casting of ring.
{@bold {@italic Enhanced Ring}}. When you cast the enhanced version of this sign, ranged attacks made from outside the ring against you are made at disadvantage.

{@bold {@italic Superior Ring}}. When you cast the superior version of this sign, the sign lasts for as long as you remain inside it. In addition, ranged attacks made from outside the ring against you or any of your allies inside are made at disadvantage.

fluff.name: The Ranger
entries: Warriors of the wilderness, rangers specialize in hunting the monsters that threaten the edges of civilization: rampaging beasts and monstrosities, terrible giants, and deadly dragons. They learn to track their quarry as a predator does, moving stealthily through the wilds and hiding themselves in brush and rubble. Rangers focus their combat training on techniques that are particularly useful against their specific favored foes.

Thanks to their familiarity with the wilds, rangers acquire the ability to cast spells that harness natures power, much as a druid does. Their spells, like their combat abilities, emphasize speed, stealth, and the hunt. A rangers talents and abilities are honed with deadly focus on the grim task of protecting the borderlands.

As masters of the art of ranged combat, rangers excel especially with ammunition weapons in their hands, but they can hold their own in closer quarters when a foe gets too close as well. Being trained marksmen, they are capable of sharpshooting feats and techniques that leave witnesses in awe.

Though a ranger might make a living as a hunter, a guide, or a tracker, a rangers true calling is to defend the outskirts of civilization from the ravages of monsters and beasts that press in from the wild.

In some places, rangers gather in secretive orders or join forces with druidic circles. Many rangers, though, are independent almost to a fault, knowing that, when a dragon or a band of orcs attacks, a ranger might be the first, and possibly the last, line of defense.

This fierce independence makes rangers well suited to adventuring, since they are accustomed to life far from the comforts of a dry bed and a hot bath. Faced with city-bred adventurers who grouse and whine about the hardships of the wild, rangers respond with some mixture of amusement, frustration, and compassion. But they quickly learn that other adventurers who can carry their own weight in a fight against civilizations foes are worth any extra burden. Coddled city folk might not know how to feed themselves or find fresh water in the wild, but they make up for it in other ways.

fluff.name: The Warlock
entries: The warlock is a practitioner of necromancy, demonic summoning, and the dark side of arcane magic. Warlocks are often ambitious and selfish individuals who covet power and dominance, with little regard for the lives of others or the costs involved. Some warlocks tend to work together for greater ends, often forming cults, and other warlocks are more independent, prefering to unravel the mysteries of forbidden magics themselves. Regardless of affiliation, warlocks are more often than not feared by the general populace, and in some societies even forbidden from entering. This often leads to warlocks hiding their identities, and disguising themselves as common travelers or sages to gain entry into towns and cities, especially since warlocks are usually hated among clerics and paladins.

default: (a) a {@table farover weapons|farover|light crossbow} and {@item Crossbow Bolts (20)|PHB|20 bolts} or (b) any {@table farover weapons|farover|simple weapon}

fluff.name: The Slayer
entries: A slayer is someone who has undergone extensive training, ruthless mental and physical conditioning, and mysterious rituals in preparation for becoming an itinerant monster slayer for hire. Slayers are trained in small batches, usually consisting of ten to fifteen kids, the vast majority of which don’t survive the training. They usually die to monsters, but even fewer survive the infamous Slayer Mutations, the final part of the process, in which the subject is subjected to toxic chemicals which, in addition to making them infertile, mutate them into something more than human.

Despite the many differences between individual slayers, such as school, personal differences, and general worldview, one thing that unites all of them is the slayer's code; the idea that a slayer doesn’t work for free. They’re not selfless heroes, they’re businessmen who provide an invaluable service to the community, and if there’s no gold to be had, there’s no slayer to be found. Although they hunt the monsters that plague the people, they are hated and feared for their unnatural appearance, a constant reminder of the evils that lurk in the world. You will never find a slayer working a guard post for a fort, since they are restless creatures, migrating across great distances, taking contracts as they go, and moving on.

tools: {@item alchemist's supplies|phb} (only usable for your Slayer Alchemy feature)

multiclassing.requirementsSpecial: When multiclassing into the slayer class, your character must endure a process of rigorous mutations which are extremely lethal. Roll {@dice 5d20} when multiclassing into the Slayer class. The result of the dice is the amount of unmitigatable poison damage you suffer.

tools: {@item alchemist's supplies|phb} (only usable for your Slayer Alchemy feature)

fluff.name: The Druid
entries: Druids belong to ancient orders that call on the forces of nature. Harnessing the magic of animals, plants, weather, and the four elements, druids can heal, transform themselves, and wield elemental destruction.

Revering nature above all, individual druids gain their magic from a nature deity, from nature itself, or both, and they form circles with other druids in performing rites and rituals to mark the passage of the seasons and other natural cycles.

Druids master a very specific kind of magic, which is oriented toward nature and animals—the power of tooth and claw, of sun and moon, of fire and storm. Druids also gain the ability to take on animal forms, and some Druids focus on this practice, even to the point where they feel more natural in an animal form.

Druids are also concerned with the delicate ecological balance that sustains plant and animal life and with the need for people to live in harmony with nature, not in opposition to it. Druids are often found guarding sacred sites or watching over regions of unspoiled nature. But when a significant danger arises, threatening nature’s balance or the lands they protect, druids take a more active role as adventurers who combat the threat.

default: (a) a {@table farover armor and shields|farover|shield} or (b) {@table farover armor and shields|farover|any simple weapon}
Any {@table farover armor and shields|farover|simple weapon}
