classFeature.name: Channel Nature
entries: The magic of nature infuses you. Tapping into that power, you can create various magical effects. You start with one such effect: Wild Shape, which is described below. Other druid features give additional Channel Nature effect options. Each time you use Channel Nature, you choose which effect to create from among those you have from this class.

You can use Channel Nature twice. You regain one expended use when you finish a short rest, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest. You gain additional uses when you reach certain druid levels, as shown in the Channel Nature column of the druid table.
If a Channel Nature effect requires a saving throw, the DC equals your spellcasting Spell Save DC.

entries.name: Wild Shape
entries: As a bonus action, you transform into a form that you have learned for this feature. You start by knowing the {@link Beasts of the Land forms|https://5e.tools/bestiary.html#agile%20beast%20of%20the%20land_farover,fbsr:wild%20shapes}. Choose one of the stat blocks available to you for the wild shape. The magic of the wild shape lasts for up to an amount of hours equal to your druid level, during which you can revert out and in of the form you chose using a bonus action for as long as the effect remains active. The effect ends early if you fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die.

While in a Wild Shape form, many of its game statistics replace yours, and your ability to handle objects is determined by the forms limbs, rather than your own. You retain your personality and memories, but lose the ability to speak. While transformed into the form, you have resistance to all types of damage, but you lose access to the following class features: {@classFeature Spellcasting|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1} (you can continue to concentrate on spells), and {@italic Channel Nature}.

When you transform in or out of the form, you are freed from any effects causing you to be {@condition grappled}. You also choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space or merges into your new form. Any unworn or unequipped equipment you have that merges with the form when you transform has no effect until you leave the form, and neither does any mundane armor, weapons, or worn equipment.

Magical armor, weapons, and other magical equipment you wear when you transform do retain all of their magical benefits, but not their mundane ones. For example, if you transform while wearing a set of +1 leather armor, you retain the magical +1 AC benefit, but not the AC of the leather armor itself. If you wield magical weapons, you can benefit from the magical property of one weapon when attacking in your wild shape form (if you’re wielding two weapons, you decide which one of the two to benefit from when you transform).

classFeature.name: Druidic
entries: You know Druidic, the secret language of druids. You can speak the language and use it to leave hidden messages. You and others who know this language automatically spot such a message. Others spot the message’s presence with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check but can’t decipher it without magic.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: Drawing on the divine power of nature itself, you can cast spells to shape that power to your will. See {@link chapter 10|https://5e.tools/book.html#PHB,10} for the general rules of spellcasting and the {@link druid spell list here|https://5e.tools/spells.html#blankhash,flstclass:druid=1}.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: At 1st level, you know two cantrips of your choice from the druid spell list. You learn additional druid cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Druid table.

entries.name: Preparing and Casting Spells
entries: {@bold {@italic Spell Slots.}} The Druid table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your druid spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these druid spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

{@bold {@italic Prepared Spells.}} You prepare the list of druid spells that are available for you to cast, choosing from the druid spell list. The level and number of druid spells you can prepare is equal to your spell slots. For example, as a 4th-level druid, you can prepare four 1st-level spells and two 2nd-level spells.

You can also change your list of prepared spells when you finish a rest. Preparing a new list of druid spells requires time spent in prayer and meditation: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your druid spells, since your magic draws upon your devotion and attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a druid spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast a druid spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag and you have the spell prepared.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use a {@item druidic focus|phb} as a spellcasting focus for your druid spells.

classFeature.name: Nature's Aid
entries: At 2nd level, you learn two more ways to use your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1} feature, as described below.

entries.name: Healing Blossoms
entries: As an action, you channel healing energy that appears as blooming flowers. Choose a point within 60 feet of you, and a surge of rejuvenating growth affects creatures there within a 10-foot radius. Roll a number of {@dice d4}‘s equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of one die). Up to 3 creatures of your choice in the area regain hit points equal to the rolled amount.
The size of the dice rolled for this feature increases to {@dice d6}‘s at 9th level, and {@dice d8}‘s at 16th level.

entries.name: Nature Spirit
entries: As a free action, you summon an ethereal fey spirit to aid you for 1 minute. The spirit is untargetable and immune to all damage, and it hovers in the air for the duration, closely following you around. While the spirit is active, it can shoulder some of the burdens of your spellcasting by being able to concentrate on a spell on your behalf. This means that if you cast a {@condition concentration} spell while the spirit is active, the spell does not require concentration on it from you, and the spirit does it instead. You can also cast a second concentration spell while the spirit is already concentrating on one, and concentrate on the second spell yourself.

Your magic is closely linked with that of the fey spirit, meaning that upon taking damage, you must make Constitution saving throws on behalf of the spirit so it can maintain concentration, but you do so at advantage when you are not concentrating on a spell and only the spirit is. If both of you are concentrating on a spell, you roll normally, and on a failed save, both spells being concentrated on end.
After a minute has passed the fey spirit disappears, and any spell it was concentrating on ends, regardless of the spells duration.
While the nature spirit is active, you can not use your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape} feature.

classFeature.name: Druidic Affinity
entries: At 3rd level, your make your choice of which druidic specialization to assume in your efforts to preserve the balance of nature. Your choice grants you features again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Might of the Land
entries: Your connection to the land deepens at 5th level, empowering the {@link Beasts of the Land forms|https://5e.tools/bestiary.html#agile%20beast%20of%20the%20land_farover,fbsr:wild%20shapes} of your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape} feature. You unlock the climbing speed and multiattack features of the forms.

classFeature.name: Tiny Creature
entries: At 5th level, you gain the ability to become a Tiny creature. When you transform into a Wild Shape form, you can instead choose to use the stat block of {@link any beast that is size Tiny|https://5e.tools/bestiary.html#awakened%20rat_wdh,flstsource:idrotf=2,flopsource:extend,flsttype:beast=1,floptype:extend,flstsize:t=1,flopsize:extend}. You still use your own hit points and hit dice when in a tiny beast form.

classFeature.name: Druidic Affinity Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your Druidic Affinity.

classFeature.name: Aquatic Form
entries: At 7th level, you learn new types of forms for your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape} feature, the {@link Creatures of the Sea|https://5e.tools/bestiary.html#agile%20beast%20of%20the%20land_farover,fbsr:wild%20shapes}.

classFeature.name: Hybrid Form
entries: Once you reach 7th level, you learn to use your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1} feature to assume a hybrid were-animal form.

entries.name: Hybrid Shape
entries: Similarly to your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape}, you assume a half-humanoid, half-animal hybrid form. When assuming a hybrid form, you can choose any {@link wild shape statblock|https://5e.tools/bestiary.html#agile%20beast%20of%20the%20land_farover,fbsr:wild%20shapes} you have access to. Since you only partially transform into the animal, you can only receive some of the features of the stat block, which are the {@bold passive features, senses, and speeds}. You choose which of these features to gain. You do not gain resistance to all damage in the hybrid form.

By only partially transforming, you do not lose access to any of your other druid features like you normally do while in a wild shape form. You can decide if you lose access to your limbs or ability to speak.

As with wild shape, you choose the animal to base the transformation on, and it does not affect on the form’s capabilities. You can choose any appropriate animal to mimic, and which features of that animal you wish to visually adopt.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Aerial Form
entries: At 9th level, you learn new types of forms for your Wild Shape feature, the {@link Birds of the Sky|https://5e.tools/bestiary.html#agile%20beast%20of%20the%20land_farover,fbsr:wild%20shapes}.

classFeature.name: Displacing Transformation
entries: Starting at 9th level, whenever you initially spend a {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1} to assume a Wild Shape form, you can choose to also teleport up to 30 feet away to an unoccupied space that you can see immediately before you transform.

Additonally, you can now also spend a Channel Nature to assume a Wild Shape form as a reaction, which you can take when you are hit with a damaging attack. You are granted your forms damage resistance against the attack, and you can also teleport as part of the reaction. If the teleportation brings you to a space where the attack could not hit you, you are unaffected by the attack.

You do not lose any other active Channel Nature effects when you transform as a reaction, but to keep those effects active, you can immediately transform out of the form after the attack as part of the same reaction. If you decide to stay in your form, any other active Channel Nature effects end.

classFeature.name: Druidic Affinity Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your Druidic Affinity.

classFeature.name: Nature's Retribution
entries: At 11th level, you learn a new way to use your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1}, as described below.

entries.name: Force of Nature
entries: As an action, you harness the surrounding magic of nature and awaken vengeful treants to harm your enemies. The treants appear at unoccupied spaces of your choice you can see within 30 feet of you, and you summon an amount of them equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded down). The treants will fight for you, attacking your designated enemies for up to 1 minute, or until they drop to 0 hit points. The treants use the {@creature awakened tree} stat block, but they are size Medium, have a speed of 30, and don’t have any resistances.

The treants take their turns as a group immediately after yours, and they will only fight your enemies. They will not perform any other actions, and if you have no enemies to fight, they will stand idly until a minute has passed and they disappear.
You can only have one use of this feature active at a time, and while the treants are active, you can not use your {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape} feature.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Beast Spells
entries: Beginning at 13th level, you can cast many of your druid spells in any shape you assume using Wild Shape. You can cast {@link spells with a range of Self or Touch|https://5e.tools/spells.html#flmtclasses:b1,flstclass:druid=1,flopclass:extend,flnhsubclass:druid=1,flopsubclass:extend,flstrange:self=1~touch=1~self%20(area)=1,floprange:extend}. You can perform the verbal and somatic components of such spells while in a wild shape and your wild shape itself acts as your spellcasting focus.

classFeature.name: Druidic Affinity Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your Druidic Affinity.

classFeature.name: Harmonize with Nature
entries: Starting at 15th level, during a short rest you may choose to meditate and harmonize with your surroundings. If you do, at the end of your rest you attune to the area in a 5-mile radius around you. You magically know what types of creatures are present in your attuned area, their approximate numbers, and if there are any magics disturbing the natural order in your attuned area. While in your attuned area, you have advantage on {@skill Nature}, {@skill Perception}, and {@skill Survival} checks, and {@sense blindsight} out to a range of 30 feet. Once attuned to an area, you remain attuned for the next 24 hours. You can only attune to one area at a time.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Elemental Destruction
entries: At 18th level, you can turn nature in its rawest elements into deadly weapons no matter your form. Once each turn, you can use a bonus action to choose a target point within 30 feet and one of the following element options. If the element you choose is not present at or near the target point, any damage dealt by this feature is halved, you have disadvantage on your spell attack, and creatures have advantage on any saving throws made to resist it.

{@bold {@italic Air.}} Each creature within 20 feet of the point must make a Strength saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes bludgeoning damage equal to {@dice 3d8} + your Wisdom modifier and is flung up 20 feet away from the target point in a random direction (determined by the roll of the first {@dice d8}) and knocked prone.

If a thrown target strikes an object, such as a wall or floor, the target takes an additional {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage. If a target is thrown at another creature, that creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or it also takes {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage and is knocked prone. If the saving throw is successful, the target takes half the bludgeoning damage and isn’t flung away or knocked prone.

{@bold {@italic Earth.}} Clumps of dirt and stone explode outward. Creatures within 10 feet of the point must make a Strength saving throw, or take {@dice 4d8} bludgeoning damage and are knocked prone. On a successful save a creature takes half damage is not knocked prone.

{@bold {@italic Fire.}} Flames roil outward in a burst of inferno. Creatures within 15 feet of the point must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@dice 6d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

{@bold {@italic Ice.}} You condense and flash freeze the water from a vast area above you into a massive boulder to drop down with immense force. Make a ranged spell attack against a creature at least 30 feet below the target point. On a hit, the creature takes {@dice 4d6} bludgeoning damage and {@dice 4d6} cold damage.

{@bold {@italic Water.}} You create a 20-foot tall, 20-foot wide wave that travels 30 feet in one direction and then crashes down. Any Large or smaller creatures and objects in the wave’s path must make a Strength saving throw. On a failure, a creature takes {@dice 4d8} bludgeoning damage and is carried with the wave. A creature that succeeds on its saving throw takes no damage and is not moved.

{@bold {@italic Wood.}} Splinters appear and fling themselves into flesh and armor alike. Creatures within 20 feet of the point must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@dice 4d6} piercing damage, or half as much on a success.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Archdruid
entries: At 20th level, when you roll initiative at the beginning of combat and have no uses of {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1} left, you regain one use.

Additionally, you can ignore the verbal and somatic components of your druid spells, as well as any material components that lack a cost and aren’t consumed by a spell. You gain this benefit in both your normal shape and your beast shape from {@classFeature Channel Nature|Druid (reworked)|Farover|1||Wild Shape}.

classFeature.name: Favored Enemy
entries: Beginning at 1st level, you have significant experience studying, tracking, and hunting a certain type of enemy encountered in the wilds.
Choose a type of favored enemy: aberrations, beasts, elementals, fey, fiends, monstrosities, oozes, plants, or undead.
You have advantage on Wisdom (Survival) checks to track your favored enemies, as well as on Intelligence checks to recall information about them.

In addition, while you see a creature that is your favored enemy and it is within 120 feet of you, you can use an action to quietly observe and learn the creatures movement speed, its Strength, Dexterity, and Constitution scores, and any immunities it might have.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain one use of it when you finish a short rest, and all uses of it when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Hunter's Mark
entries: At 1st level, you gain the ability to magically mark a creature you can see within 90 feet as your quarry with a bonus action. For 1 hour, you deal an extra {@dice 1d4} damage to the target whenever you hit it with a weapon attack, and you have advantage on any Wisdom (Perception) or Wisdom (Survival) check you make to find it. You can only have one Hunter's Mark active at a time.
The damage of Hunter's Mark is increased to {@dice 1d6} at 9th level, and {@dice 1d8} at 17th level.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to 1 + your Wisdom modifier. If you use this feature against your favored enemy, you do not need to spend a use of it. You regain one use of this feature when you finish a short rest, and all uses of it when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: By the time you reach 2nd level, you have learned to use the magical essence of nature to cast spells, much as a druid does. See chapter 10 of the PHB for the general rules of spellcasting, and page 8 for the ranger {@filter spell list|spells|class=ranger;ranger (FO)}.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Ranger table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your {@filter ranger spells|spells|class=ranger;ranger (FO)} of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell animal friendship} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell animal friendship} using either slot.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: You know three 1st-level spells of your choice from the ranger {@filter spell list|spells|class=ranger;ranger (FO)}.

The Spells Known column of the Ranger table shows when you learn more ranger spells of your choice. Each of these spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots. For instance, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can learn one new spell of 1st or 2nd level.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your ranger spells, since your magic draws on your attunement to nature. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a ranger spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use any weapon made of wood, such as a longbow, as a spellcasting focus for your ranger spells.

classFeature.name: Steady Aim
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, you can give yourself advantage on your first ranged attack roll of the turn by not using any movement during that turn. You can do this only if you haven't moved during this turn, and after you give yourself advantage, your speed is 0 until the end of the current turn.

classFeature.name: Natural Explorer
entries: At 3rd level, you become adept at navigating the natural world, and you react with swift and decisive action when attacked. This grants you the following benefits in combat and when travelling for an hour or more:

As masters of the art of ranged combat, rangers excel especially with ammunition weapons in their hands, but they can hold their own in closer quarters when a foe gets too close as well. Being trained marksmen, they are capable of sharpshooting feats and techniques that leave witnesses in awe.

items: You have advantage on initiative rolls.
On your first turn during combat, you have advantage on attack rolls against creatures that have not yet acted.
Your group can't become lost except by magical means.
Even when you are engaged in another activity while traveling (such as navigating or tracking), you remain alert to danger.
If you are traveling alone, you can move stealthily at a normal pace.
When you forage, you find twice as much food as you normally would.
While tracking other creatures, you also learn their exact number, their sizes, and how long ago they passed through the area.

entries: In addition, you have an innate ability to communicate with beasts, and they recognize you as a kindred spirit. Through sounds and gestures, you can communicate simple ideas to a beast as an action, and can read its basic mood and intent. You learn its emotional state, whether it is affected by magic of any sort, its short-term needs (such as food or safety), and actions you can take (if any) to persuade it to not attack.
You cannot use this ability against a creature that you have attacked within the past 10 minutes.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave
entries: At 3rd level, you choose to emulate the ideals and training of a ranger conclave from the list of available conclaves on page 5. Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 7th, 11th, and 15th level.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Shot Mastery
entries: At 5th level, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn, you can attack twice, instead of once.

In addition, your expertise with missile weapons unlocks an advanced tier of shot options for you. Whenever you take the Attack action on your turn with a ranged weapon, you can make one special weapon attack, instead of attacking twice.

When making one of these special weapon attacks, any additional damage you might deal from spells, other features, or other sources as part of the attack can only apply to one creature hit. You have four choices of special attacks:

entries.name: Curving Shot
entries: When making a curving shot, make an attack roll against a target you can see or at a square in a location you are aware of within range, regardless of cover. As long as there is a path for the projectile, and the target doesn't have full cover from all sides, your shot can travel around cover and hit your target. The range of your weapon for this shot is halved, as are any long range disadvantages that apply to your weapon. Your attack roll ignores any AC cover benefits that aren't full cover.

entries.name: Multi Shot
entries: When making a multi shot, you load your weapon with up to four ammunition for a single shot that can hit multiple enemies in front of you. Make an attack roll with your weapon as normal. The attack roll you make can hit up to four creatures of your choice inside a 40-foot cone originating from you, as long as they are not behind any cover at all, including that from other creatures. If a creature is behind any cover at all, the attack misses against that target.

entries.name: Piercing Shot
entries: When making a piercing shot, make an attack roll as normal against an enemy in range. Regardless of if the attack hits the target or not, the projectile pierces or flies past the enemy, and it can hit up to 3 additional creatures if they are inside a 5-foot wide line connecting from you, through the initial target that was attacked, to them. The same attack roll is used for each target. Even if the attack roll misses a target, the projectile continues flying until it hits 4 creatures in total, or terrain, or an object. The projectile can not fly further than the range of your weapon, and long range disadvantages apply as normal.

entries.name: Volley Shot
entries: When making a volley shot, you load your weapon with up to four ammunition for a volley strike from the sky within range. Make one weapon attack as normal. The range of your weapon for this shot is halved, as are any long range disadvantages that apply to your weapon. Your attack can then hit up to four targets within 5 feet of a point you shoot at.

classFeature.name: Greater Favored Enemy
entries: At 6th level, you are ready to adopt a second favored enemy, and the knowledge you have of your favored enemies is expanded. Choose one additional type of favored enemy. This can be any type of creature, except humanoids.

You also gain added benefits when it comes to interacting with your favored enemies. When using an action to quietly observe a favored enemy, you also learn its natural or unarmored AC, its current hit points, and any resistances or vulnerabilities it might have.
In addition, when you attack a favored enemy that is affected by your Hunter's Mark feature, the damage die of the mark increases by one die size.

classFeature.name: Primeval Awareness
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can attune your senses to determine if any of your favored enemies lurk nearby. By spending 1 uninterrupted minute in concentration (as if you were concentrating on a spell), you can sense whether any of your favored enemies are present within 5 miles of you. This feature reveals which of your favored enemies are present, their numbers, and the creatures' general direction and distance (in miles) from you.
If there are multiple groups of your favored enemies within range, you learn this information for each group.
You can use this feature an amount of times equal to your Wisdom modifier, and you restore all uses of it on a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Fleet of Foot
entries: Beginning at 8th level, you can use the Dash action as a bonus action on your turn, and when you do so, you ignore difficult terrain for the rest of your turn.

classFeature.name: Survival Expert
entries: At 9th level, you gain expertise in the Survival skill, doubling your proficiency bonus. If you are not proficient in Survival, you instead gain proficiency.

classFeature.name: Point-Blank Maneuverability
entries: Starting at 10th-level, you can no longer have disadvantage on ranged attacks while a hostile creature is within 5 feet of you.
Additionally, if you attack a creature on your turn, you don't provoke opportunity attacks from that creature for the rest of the turn. This feature can only affect one enemy creature per turn.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave Feature
entries: At 11th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Further Favored Enemies
entries: When you reach 13th level, you can choose a third type of favored enemy. This favored enemy can be any type of creature, except humanoids.

classFeature.name: Cloak of Nature
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can spend 1 minute creating an effective camouflage for yourself. You must have access to fresh mud, dirt, plants, soot, and other naturally occurring materials with which to create your camouflage.

Once you are camouflaged in this way, you are practically invisible. As long as you don't take any damage and don't move more than 15 feet per round, you will remain invisible to others. Otherwise, this invisibility lasts until you finish a short rest. Any spells or effects that reveal invisible creatures will still reveal you.

classFeature.name: Ranger Conclave Feature
entries: At 15th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Ranger Conclave.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Feral Senses
entries: At 18th level, you gain preternatural senses that help you fight creatures you can't see. When you attack a creature you can't see, your inability to see it doesn't impose disadvantage on your attack rolls against it. You are also aware of the location of any invisible creature within 30 feet of you, provided that the creature isn't hidden from you and you aren't blinded or deafened.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Foe Slayer
entries: At 20th level, you become an unparalleled hunter. When you roll initiative at the beginning of combat and have no uses of Hunter's Mark left, you regain one use.

Additionally, once on each of your turns, you can add your Wisdom modifier to the attack roll or the damage roll of an attack you make. You can choose to use this feature before or after the roll, but before any effects of the roll are applied.

classFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: You have studied and learned to manipulate the forces of arcane magic to grant you power and dominance.

entries.name: Cantrips
entries: You know two cantrips of your choice from the warlock {@filter spell list|spells|class=warlock;warlock (FO)}. You learn additional warlock cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the warlock table.

entries.name: Spell Slots
entries: The warlock table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your warlock spells of 1st through 5th level. The table also shows what the level of those slots is; all of your spell slots are the same level. To cast one of your warlock spells of 1st level or higher, you must expend a spell slot. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a short or long rest.
For example, when you are 5th level, you have two 3rd-level spell slots. To cast the 1st-level spell {@spell Cause Fear|xge}, you must spend one of those slots, and you cast it as a 3rd-level spell.

entries.name: Spells Known of 1st Level and Higher
entries: At 1st level, you know three 1st spells of your choice from the warlock {@filter spell list|spells|class=warlock;warlock (FO)}, and you learn an additional warlock spell of your choice at each level after that.

The Spells Known column of the warlock table shows when you learn more warlock spells of your choice of 1st level and higher. A spell you choose to learn must be of a level no higher than what's shown in the table's Slot Level column for your level.

In addition, at 2nd level you learn one additional special warlock spell called a {@filter dread spell|spells|subschool=Dread}. You learn one new dread spell every even level you gain in the warlock class, as shown in the Dread Spells Known column of the warlock table.

items: Dread spells are cast with {@classFeature soul shards|Warlock (reworked)|farover|2} instead of spell slots, and dread spells are always cast at the highest possible level.
A dread spell you learn must be of a level equal to what's shown in the table's Slot Level column for your level.

entries: When you reach 6th level, for example, you learn a new warlock spell, which can be 1st, 2nd, or 3rd level, and you also learn one new dread spell, which can be 1st, 2nd, or 3rd level.

entries.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your warlock spells, so you use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a warlock spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

entries.name: Ritual Casting
entries: You can cast any warlock spell as a ritual if that spell has the ritual tag.

entries.name: Spellcasting Focus
entries: You can use an arcane focus or a component pouch as a spellcasting focus for your warlock spells.

classFeature.name: Demonic Fortitude
entries: At 1st level, the interior of your body adapts some fiendish characteristics, making your body more resilient. While you are wearing no armor and not wielding a shield, your AC equals 13 + your Constitution modifier.
In addition, when you willingly inflict damage to yourself with a warlock class feature, you do not have to make a Constitution saving throw to maintain concentration on a spell.

classFeature.name: Soul Shards
entries: At 2nd level, your intricate knowledge of life, death and souls has granted you the ability to harvest fragments of souls from the enemies that you slay. Soul shards are physical objects that you carry, resembling small, whitish pink crystals.

Once per day, when a creature you can see and have damaged within one round of combat dies, you can use your reaction to harvest a fragment of the soul from the creature, creating a soul shard. You can also do this later with an action within 5 feet and 1 hour of the creature dying, before it's soul parts ways with it's body. Creatures that are either undead, constructs, or have a CR of 0 do not give soul shards.
In addition to this, you also gain one soul shard every short rest, and all soul shards up to your total maximum on a long rest.
You can store a maximum amount of soul shards as indicated on the warlock table.
You can use one soul shard for one of the following two effects:

items: You can use a soul shard to cast certain powerful warlock spells called {@filter dread spells|spells|subschool=Dread}. Dread spells are spells that can be cast only with soul shards.
You can use a soul shard to summon a fiend to serve you with your {@classFeature demonic summoning|Warlock (reworked)|farover|5} feature.

entries: When you use a soul shard, you suffer {@dice 1d4} {@bold unmitigatable force damage} per level of the spell cast.

classFeature.name: Cult Pledge
entries: At 2nd level, you align yourself with one of the secret, widespread cults specializing in a certain dark practice. Your choice grants you features at 2nd level and again at 6th, 10th, and 14th level.

Different warlocks choose different dark arts to follow and practice. All of these arts are practiced by a widespread, specialized cult that shares it's secrets with it's members. The cult pledge you choose to follow reflects your approach.

classFeature.name: Life Tap
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can sacrifice some of your health for spell slots. With a bonus action and by harnessing your own life energy, you can sacrifice an amount of hit points {@bold equal to your warlock level}, and use it to recover one expended warlock spell slot.
You can use this feature an amount of times equal to your Intelligence modifier, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Demonic Summoning
entries: At 5th level, your knowledge grants you insight on how to interact with the plane of shadow, and summon a fiend from it to your plane of existence. By spending a Soul Shard and 10 minutes casting a ritual, you can force a fiend to be summoned within 10 feet of you, and bind it to serve you under the threat of death. The fiend summoned will arrive against it's will, but will follow your commands in hopes of either being released, or falling in battle, which would both return it to the plane of shadow. Disobeying your commands would cause the fiend to turn to dust, and truly die.

You can issue commands telepathically to your summoned fiend, and in general interact with it only while you are within 500 feet of it. Even if you and your summon don't share a language, it will understand simple commands from you. Your summon can not communicate information back to you unless it shares a language with you. If it does not have any active commands, it will simply return to you. In combat your summon takes it's turn immediately after yours, and will act based on your commands. If your summon is beyond 500 feet of you, it will still follow your last command to the best of it's ability, and in combat it will otherwise simply take the dodge action.

You can release your summon at any time back to the plane of shadow as an action. You can also dismiss your summon into a pocket dimension as an action, where it will await your summon. Retrieving your summon from the pocket dimension requires a 10 minute ritual.

Your summon recovers all of its hit points when you complete a short rest. If you fall unconscious, your summon is sent to the pocket dimension. If you die, your summon is released. You can only have one summon active at a time.
Your summoned fiends use {@filter different stat blocks|bestiary|search=summoned}, unlike their normal counterparts.

At 5th level, you can summon an {@creature Summoned imp|farover|imp}. Summoning an Imp is considered a 1st level spell for the purpose of Soul Shard damage. At 11th and at 18th level, you gain a new summon.

classFeature.name: Cult Pledge Feature
entries: At 6th level, you gain a feature granted by your cult pledge.

classFeature.name: Soulstones
entries: At 7th level, you learn how to contort your acquired soul shards into a new form, called Soulstones. Creating a soulstone costs one soul shard, takes 1 minute, and is considered a 3rd level spell for the purpose of soul shard damage. You can only have one soulstone at a time. Making a new soulstone requires the previous soulstone to be destroyed. The soulstone weighs 1 lb., is the size of a fist, is immune to poison and psychic damage, has 10 hit points, and has 10 AC. A soulstone effect is a shared effect between two willing creatures, one of which can be the warlock.
A soulstone can be used to link two willing creatures together in {@bold one} of two ways:

items: {@bold {@italic Soul Bond}}: The warlock can power the soulstone and create a bond between the souls of two characters, giving the soulstone to one of them to keep. While bonded, whenever one of the two characters suffer damage, they only suffer half of that damage, and the other bonded character suffers the rest. The effect has no maximum range, and affects the characters as long as they are both on the same plane of existence.

{@bold {@italic Soul Revive}}: The warlock can power the soulstone and connect the life force of two characters together, giving the soulstone to one of them to keep. When either of the two characters would then fall below 1 hit point from damage, the soulstone causes that character to mitigate any of the excess damage suffered beyond 1 hit point, at the cost of the other connected characters hit points. The effect converts an amount of hit points equal to how many points of damage is mitigated, but it can not bring the hit points of the character whos hit points are converted below 1. When this effect happens, the soulstone breaks and is destroyed.

entries: Both effects persist until the soulstone is destroyed, or if the soulstone is not in possession of one of the two characters. If a soulstone is not in possession of one of the two characters, the soulstone decays and is destroyed.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ritual of Summoning
entries: At 9th level, your extended knowledge of the planes of existence grants you the ability to summon willing creatures to you if they are on the same plane as you.

By spending 10 minutes casting a ritual with the aid of at least two other characters, you can summon a willing creature to your location if you are both on the same plane of existence. When the ritual is completed, the creature being summoned feels a pull in their gut, signaling teleportation. The character being summoned has the option of declining the summon by resisting against it.
You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.

classFeature.name: Cult Pledge Feature
entries: At 10th level, you gain a feature granted by your cult pledge.

classFeature.name: Versatile Shards (6th Level)
entries: At 11th level, you learn how to utilize your soul shards even further.
You can now use a soul shard to cast a normal 6th level warlock spell once without expending a spell slot, and without suffering any soul shard damage.
At higher levels, you gain the ability to cast higher level spells in this way as well: one 7th-level spell at 13th level, one 8th-level spell at 15th level, and one 9th-level spell at 17th level.
You can use your soul shards to cast the spells from each of these features only once, but you can use a higher level versatile shard use to cast a lower level versatile shard spell as well.
You regain all uses of these features on a long rest.

classFeature.name: Improved Demonic Summoning
entries: At 11th level, you can now summon a {@creature Summoned hell hound|farover|hell hound} with your Demonic Summoning. Summoning a Hell Hound is considered a 3rd level spell for the purpose of Soul Shard damage.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Versatile Shards (7th Level)
entries: At 13th level, you can now use a soul shard to cast a normal 7th level warlock spell, without suffering any soul shard damage.
You can use this feature once, and you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Cult Pledge Feature
entries: At 14th level, you gain a feature granted by your cult pledge.

classFeature.name: Versatile Shards (8th Level)
entries: At 15th level, you can now use a soul shard to cast a normal 8th level warlock spell, without suffering any soul shard damage.
You can use this feature once, and you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Versatile Shards (9th Level)
entries: At 17th level, you can now use a soul shard to cast a normal 9th level warlock spell, without suffering any soul shard damage.
You can use this feature once, and you must finish a long rest before you can do so again.

classFeature.name: Greater Demonic Summoning
entries: At 18th level, you can now summon a {@creature Summoned Armanite|farover|armanite} with your Demonic Summoning. Summoning an Armanite is considered a 5th level spell for the purpose of Soul Shard damage.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Eldritch Master
entries: At 20th level, you can now harvest an unlimited amount of soul shards each day.

classFeature.name: Mutations
entries: Starting at 1st level, the rigorous, inhumane mutations you have been subjected to begin to manifest. Your reflexes, strength, and senses all trump those of a normal humanoids. You gain the following benefits:

items: If you wield a weapon with the Versatile property, you also gain the Finesse property for that weapon.
You gain {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet.

You gain proficiency in {@skill Perception}, and you can sense creatures you can't see within 30 feet by smell. Sensing a creature by smell only informs you of the existence of the creature within 30 feet, but not it's exact location.
When making checks to track or recall general information about any non-humanoid creature, you have advantage on the roll.

entries: Your mutations will continue to develop, granting you additional benefits at 7th and 14th levels.

classFeature.name: Signs
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you learn to cast simple arcane magic called {@filter signs|optionalfeatures|feature type=ss}. Though they are not wizards who employ powerful magic, slayers can cast simple magic spells that can prove effective when used properly. Slayers call these spells signs and usually use them in combat, though they also have non-combat applications. Because of the signs, slayers prefer single weapons since they need a free hand to cast them. Some of the signs are cast by arranging the fingers in specific way, while others have to be drawn on a surface or in the air. Signs are very subtle, only requiring a somatic component, and most people do not even realize when a sign has been cast. Slayers do not need to hold a spellcasting focus for their signs, instead they simply channel the magic through their {@item slayer medallion|farover}, which they wear around their neck.

At 2nd level, you know two signs of your choice from the list of {@filter signs|optionalfeatures|feature type=ss}. You learn additional signs of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Signs Known column of the Slayer table. You can cast your signs using vigor points.

entries.name: Vigor Points
entries: Casting your signs costs you vigor points. Vigor points are an expendable resource, and the amount of vigor points you have is shown in the Vigor Points column of the Slayer table. On a short rest, you regain an amount of vigor points equal to your proficiency bonus, and on a long rest, you regain all of your vigor points.

A basic sign costs 2 vigor points. At later levels, you learn how to cast empowered versions of your signs. When casting a sign of a higher version, the sign retains its effects and benefits from all of the lesser versions.
At 6th level, you learn how to cast enhanced signs, which cost 3 vigor points. At 10th level, you learn how to cast superior signs, which cost 5 vigor points.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: Some of your signs require your targets to make a saving throw to resist the sign's effects. The saving throw DC is calculated as follows:

classFeature.name: Slayer School
entries: Starting at 3rd level, slayers decide which school they want to follow. Each school offers a variety of skills, techniques and knowledge, which reflects the approach of it's members.
Your choice grants you features at 3rd level and again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Slayer Alchemy
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn how to craft {@filter special consumable items|optionalfeatures|feature type=sp;sm} with your {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb} made specifically for slayers. These potent consumables are poisonous for normal humanoids, but your mutations allow your body to digest them only at the cost of some side effects. If a non-slayer consumes a product of slayer alchemy, the item's effects are not applied, but they must succeed on a DC 18 Constitution saving throw, or be poisoned until they finish a long rest.

At 3rd level, you can craft both {@filter potions|optionalfeatures|feature type=sp} and {@filter mutagens|optionalfeatures|feature type=sm}, and you know the formulae to create four potions and/or mutagens. You learn two additional formulae each time you gain a level in this class.

Crafting your consumable items with your Slayer Alchemy is done when you finish a short or long rest. Each item crafted takes 1 minute. You can create a number of items up to an amount equal to your {@bold {@italic Wisdom modifier + your proficiency bonus}}. You can craft multiples of one kind of item. Unconsumed items created by your slayer alchemy only last until you finish your next short rest, after which they lose their potency and become inert, which means unused items must be remade each short rest if they are to be used.
{@bold {@italic Potions.}} Slayer {@filter potions|optionalfeatures|feature type=sp} can be consumed with a bonus action, and they last for varied amounts of time.

{@bold {@italic Mutagens.}} Slayer {@filter mutagens|optionalfeatures|feature type=sm} can be consmued with an action, and they last until you finish a long rest. You gain toxicity when you consume a mutagen, and toxicity gained from a mutagen can not be lost by resting while the mutagen remains active. While one or more mutagens are affecting you, you can use an action to focus and flush them from your system, ending the effects and side effects of all mutagens. Toxicity from mutagens is not removed when doing so.

entries.name: Toxicity
entries: With your Slayer Alchemy ability, one side effect for the consumable items is toxicity. As the resource that limits your ability to consume these items, your toxicity level rises each time you consume a toxic slayer alchemy item. Doing so, your veins and your blood become darker, turning into a black liquid when you near your toxicity limit.

The limit of your toxicity level is shown in the Toxicity Limit column of the Slayer table, and this limit increases as you gain levels in this class. If a consumable item would bring you above your toxicity limit, you can not consume that item.

Your toxicity level is completely depleted on a long rest, bringing you back to 0 toxicity. In addition, you can voluntarily lose toxicity points equal to your proficiency bonus each time you finish a short rest. If you are under the effects of a {@filter mutagen|optionalfeatures|feature type=sm}, you can not lose any toxicity points being caused by the mutagen in this way.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the Attack action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Enhanced Signs
entries: Starting at 6th level, you unlock the ability to cast stronger versions of your {@filter signs|optionalfeatures|feature type=ss}, called enhanced signs. Enhanced signs cost 3 vigor points to cast instead of 2.

classFeature.name: Improved Mutations
entries: At 7th level, your slayer mutations develop even further, granting you additional benefits:

items: You gain immunity to the negative effects of magical and non-magical {@table aging effects|farover|aging}, disease, and the {@condition poisoned} condition. Your mind still ages with time, but your body remains at the age at which you reached level 7. You can not die of old age.
You gain expertise in the {@skill Perception} skill.
You no longer need to sleep normally, and you can instead meditate, remaining semiconscious. A nights rest which is normally 8 hours requires you to only meditate for 4 hours.

classFeature.name: Heightened Observation
entries: At 7th level, your inhuman senses and vast experience allows you to learn some features about your non-humanoid enemies. By observing a monster for at least 1 minute outside of combat, you learn information about its capabilities. You can only do this to a specific creature once a day. After 1 minute of successfully observing, roll 2d6, rerolling duplicates. The result of the dice indicates the information you are able to glean, as follows:

items: {@bold {@italic 1.}} Strength or Dexterity ability score, whichever is higher
{@bold {@italic 2.}} Current hit points
{@bold {@italic 3.}} Armor class
{@bold {@italic 4.}} One resistance or immunity, if any exist
{@bold {@italic 5.}} One vulnerability, if it exists
{@bold {@italic 6.}} Charisma, Intelligence or Wisdom ability score, whichever is highest

classFeature.name: Decoctions
entries: At 11th level, your increased knowledge and developed mutations allow you to craft and digest incredibly poisonous Slayer Alchemy items called decoctions. Decoctions are made using the remains or the essence of monsters you slay as their main ingredient with your {@classFeature slayer alchemy|Slayer|farover|3} feature.

When you slay a monster, you can spend 1 minute harvesting an ingredient from it's remains. Using your {@item Alchemist's Supplies|phb}, you can craft a decoction from this ingredient. This can be done as part of your normal {@classFeature slayer alchemy|Slayer|farover|3} short rest crafting, or separately.

When you craft a decoction, you decide which one attribute from the slain monster you wish to encapsulate in the decoction, which can be {@bold an ability score, natural AC, damage resistance, damage immunity, condition immunity, or sense}. The attribute can be any specific one you are aware of, or a general one such as {@italic whatever is the creatures highest ability score}. Work with your DM to determine the attribute, since your DM might not reveal unknown attributes of a creature.
You can only have one decoction at a time. To harvest the ingredient for a second decoction means you have to consume or discard the first decoction.

You can consume a decoction as an action, and it's effects last for 1 minute. For the duration, you gain the attribute of the monster from which the decoction was made. Consuming a decoction increases your toxicity by 5.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Slayer School Feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Slayer School.

classFeature.name: Superior Signs
entries: Starting at 10th level, you unlock the ability to cast the strongest versions of your {@filter signs|optionalfeatures|feature type=ss}, called superior signs. Superior signs cost 5 vigor points.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Slayer School Feature
entries: At 13th level, you gain a feature granted to you by your Slayer School.

classFeature.name: Finalized Mutations
entries: At 14th level, your slayer mutations begin to complete themselves into their perfected form. You gain the following benefits:

items: You can't be surprised, unless you are meditating.
You gain resistance to poison damage.
You gain proficiency in Constitution saving throws.

classFeature.name: Venomous Body
entries: Starting at 15th level, when an enemy hits you with a melee attack, you can use your reaction to cause the enemy to suffer poison damage. The attacking creature must make a Consitution saving throw against your sign save DC, suffering poison damage equal to your current toxicity level on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

classFeature.name: Master Slayer
entries: At 20th level, you achieve the rank of master slayer, due to your vast experience, knowledge, and training. You gain the following benefits:

items: You learn to fully utilize your superhuman senses, granting you {@sense truesight} out to the same range as your {@sense darkvision}.
You can now sense creatures you can't see by smell within 60 feet, and if you do, you immediately know their location and type.
Whenever you score a critical hit with a weapon attack, you can cast one sign as a free action.
